title: Desire Reignition Style
research: Based on research into long-term desire and Esther Perel's work on erotic intelligence.
description: This theme encourages couples to explore what initially sparked their passion, rediscovering elements of mystery, novelty, and attraction in their relationship.

Introduce a new hobby or interest you can share.

title: Honesty Spectrum Type

If you chose option 4) frequently, your style is Protective Withholding, suggesting you tend to hold back information to avoid potential conflicts.

title: Honesty and Openness Style
research: Grounded in Carl Rogers' concept of unconditional positive regard, this test explores how individuals create non-judgmental environments for honest and open expression within their relationships.

questions.question: When your partner shares something personal, how do you usually respond?

title: Family Dynamics Type
research: Based on family systems theory and its impact on marital relationships.

title: Marriage Roles Style

title: Ritual Building Style
research: Based on research into the importance of rituals and routines in strengthening relationships.
description: This theme helps couples establish meaningful rituals, such as weekly check-ins or shared activities, to create consistency and connection in their marriage.

questions.question: How do you prefer to start your day with your partner?
options: Following a consistent morning routine together.
Starting with spontaneous activities like surprise coffee dates.
Creating unique morning rituals that reflect our personalities.
Keeping mornings simple and free from strict routines.
Taking time each morning to reflect individually before joining up.

questions.question: What kind of weekly activities do you enjoy most with your partner?
options: Scheduling regular date nights or specific activities every week.
Trying out different activities each week based on what we feel like.
Developing creative projects or hobbies together regularly.
Having flexible plans and deciding on the spot.
Engaging in quiet, reflective activities that we adjust as needed.

questions.question: When planning a special evening together, what approach do you take?
options: Planning every detail in advance to ensure everything goes smoothly.
Leaving parts of the evening open to spontaneous decisions.
Incorporating creative or unconventional elements into the evening.
Keeping it low-key and avoiding elaborate plans.
Focusing on meaningful conversations to deepen our connection.

questions.question: How do you like to celebrate anniversaries or important dates?
options: Following a traditional way of celebrating every year.
Coming up with new and unexpected ways to celebrate each time.
Creating personalized rituals that are unique to our relationship.
Keeping celebrations simple without much planning.
Taking time to reflect on our relationship and growth together.

questions.question: What role do rituals play in your daily interactions?
options: They provide structure and predictability to our relationship.
They add fun and spontaneity to our daily lives.
They allow us to express our creativity and individuality.
We prefer minimal rituals to maintain flexibility.
They offer moments for reflection and emotional connection.

questions.question: How do you handle changes in your established rituals?
options: Adhering to them strictly despite changes.
Adapting them spontaneously as needed.
Modifying them creatively to fit new circumstances.
Choosing to let go of them if they no longer fit.
Reevaluating them thoughtfully to ensure they still serve us.

questions.question: When facing a busy week, how do you maintain your rituals?
options: Stick to the rituals no matter what.
Be flexible and adjust rituals around our schedules.
Find creative ways to incorporate rituals despite the busyness.
Scale back or simplify our rituals during busy times.
Use rituals as a way to decompress and stay connected.

questions.question: How do you incorporate new traditions into your relationship?
options: Systematically adding new traditions to our routine.
Introducing new traditions spontaneously as opportunities arise.
Creating new traditions that reflect our unique bond.
Being selective and minimal about which new traditions to adopt.
Reflecting on what new traditions could enhance our relationship.

questions.question: What is your preference for evening downtime with your partner?
options: Following a consistent nightly routine together.
Spending evenings doing different spontaneous activities.
Engaging in creative or interactive evening rituals.
Keeping evenings relaxed without a set routine.
Using evenings to connect deeply through conversation or reflection.

questions.question: How do you prefer to wrap up your day as a couple?
options: With a set routine like reading together or a nightly check-in.
With spontaneous moments like watching a surprise movie.
With personalized rituals that are meaningful to us.
Without a strict routine, keeping it open-ended.
With reflective practices like journaling or discussing the day.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following ritual building styles: 1) Structured Planner, 2) Flexible Creator, 3) Creative Integrator, 4) Minimalist, 5) Reflective Improver.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Ritual Building Style is Structured Planner, indicating you prefer well-defined and consistent rituals to strengthen your relationship.

title: Stress Support Style
research: Drawn from stress management and social support research in couples, this quiz helps identify how individuals cope with stress and support their partners during challenging times.
description: Life can get stressful, but how you support each other makes all the difference! Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Stress Support Style and learn how you can better navigate tough times together.

questions.question: When you're feeling overwhelmed, how do you usually seek support from your partner?
options: I talk openly about my feelings and what's bothering me.
I prefer to have my partner handle some of my responsibilities.
I look for distractions and engage in activities to take my mind off things.
I appreciate a comforting hug or physical presence.
I tend to withdraw and need some alone time to process.

questions.question: How do you handle your partner's stress when you notice they're upset?
options: I listen actively and encourage them to share their feelings.
I offer practical solutions to help alleviate their stress.
I try to cheer them up with humor or light-hearted activities.
I provide physical comfort, like holding their hand or giving a hug.
I give them space, understanding that they need time alone.

questions.question: During a stressful situation, what's your go-to coping mechanism?
options: Talking it out with someone I trust.
Creating a plan to tackle the problem step by step.
Engaging in a fun activity to lift my mood.
Seeking physical comfort or closeness.
Taking time alone to reflect and calm down.

questions.question: How do you prefer to unwind after a tough day?
options: Having a deep conversation about the day's events.
Organizing or planning for the next day to regain control.
Watching a funny movie or playing games to relax.
Cuddling or spending quiet time together.
Spending some time alone to recharge.

questions.question: When facing a major life challenge, how do you approach it with your partner?
options: We discuss our feelings and support each other emotionally.
We break down the challenge into manageable tasks and tackle them together.
We find ways to incorporate fun to ease the tension.
We lean on each other for physical and emotional comfort.
We give each other space while staying connected.

questions.question: What role do you usually take when your partner is stressed?
options: The Listener – I'm there to hear them out.
The Organizer – I help manage the situation.
The Entertainer – I lighten the mood with fun activities.
The Comforter – I provide physical and emotional comfort.
The Space Giver – I respect their need for alone time.

questions.question: How do you communicate your needs during stressful times?
options: I express my feelings clearly and openly.
I specify what practical help I need.
I ask for activities that can help distract and relax me.
I seek physical closeness and reassurance.
I indicate when I need some time alone without much explanation.

questions.question: When your partner offers help during your stress, how do you usually respond?
options: I appreciate their support and talk about my feelings.
I accept their practical help to reduce my burden.
I enjoy engaging in a shared activity to unwind together.
I feel comforted by their physical presence and affection.
I prefer to handle it on my own and appreciate their understanding.

questions.question: How do you ensure you and your partner stay connected during stressful periods?
options: By maintaining open and honest communication.
By collaborating on solutions and supporting each other's efforts.
By finding moments to laugh and have fun together.
By being physically present and affectionate.
By allowing each other the space needed to cope individually.

questions.question: What do you value most in your partner's support during stressful times?
options: Their willingness to listen and understand.
Their ability to help solve problems effectively.
Their sense of humor and ability to make me laugh.
Their physical affection and presence.
Their respect for my need to handle things in my own way.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Stress Support Styles: 1) The Emotional Supporter, 2) The Problem Solver, 3) The Lighthearted Companion, 4) The Comfort Provider, 5) The Independence Advocate.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Stress Support Style is The Emotional Supporter, indicating you prioritize open communication and emotional connection during stressful times.

title: Tradition Balance Style
research: Derived from family systems theory and research on managing religious traditions in relationships
description: This test examines how you handle religious family traditions, expectations, and potential pressures from extended family, helping you understand your approach to maintaining harmony in your relationship.

questions.question: When faced with a religious holiday from your partner's family, you:
options: Find a way to incorporate both your traditions and theirs.
Stick strictly to your own family's traditions.
Participate occasionally but don't put much emphasis.
Follow your personal beliefs, regardless of family expectations.
Adapt based on what your partner prefers this time.

questions.question: How do you handle invitations to family religious events that clash with your plans?
options: Try to attend and engage with both families' traditions.
Prioritize your family's traditions and decline the invitation.
Attend briefly without much involvement.
Decline to maintain your personal beliefs.
Compromise by attending some parts of the event.

questions.question: When discussing religious traditions with your partner, you:
options: Explore how to blend both traditions effectively.
Express a strong preference for your own traditions.
Mention your traditions but remain flexible.
Focus on your individual beliefs without blending.
Seek mutually agreeable traditions to follow.

questions.question: If your extended family expects you to follow certain religious practices, you:
options: Incorporate some practices while respecting their expectations.
Maintain your family's religious practices without change.
Occasionally observe the practices when convenient.
Reject the practices to stay true to your beliefs.
Modify your participation based on your partner's viewpoint.

questions.question: How do you feel about blending religious traditions in your home?
options: Excited to create a unique blend that honors both cultures.
Prefer to keep each family's traditions separate and distinct.
Indifferent as long as basic practices are maintained.
Prefer to follow your own traditions exclusively.
Willing to blend traditions to maintain peace.

questions.question: When planning a family event, you:
options: Incorporate elements from both families' religious traditions.
Organize the event strictly according to your family's traditions.
Include some traditions without focusing on religious aspects.
Plan the event based on your personal preferences alone.
Work with your partner to include traditions that satisfy both sides.

questions.question: If your partner wants to adopt a religious tradition important to their family, you:
options: Embrace the tradition and find ways to include your own.
Respectfully decline and maintain your own traditions.
Participate to a limited extent without full commitment.
Choose not to adopt the tradition to stay true to yourself.
Support the adoption while finding common ground.

questions.question: How do you respond to differing religious views between you and your partner?
options: Seek to understand and integrate both perspectives.
Maintain your own views firmly without compromise.
Acknowledge differences but keep practices minimal.
Prioritize your personal beliefs over the relationship.
Find a middle path that respects both viewpoints.

questions.question: When your family invites you to religious gatherings, you:
options: Attend and engage with both families' traditions.
Attend only those gatherings that align with your traditions.
Join occasionally without deep participation.
Decline to avoid conflicting with your beliefs.
Attend selectively based on mutual agreement with your partner.

questions.question: In your daily life, you manage religious traditions by:
options: Creating new practices that reflect both your backgrounds.
Following your family's traditional practices exclusively.
Incorporating traditions when convenient but not strictly.
Ignoring religious traditions to focus on personal beliefs.
Balancing traditions through cooperation and flexibility.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following tradition balance styles: 1) Integrator, 2) Traditionalist, 3) Casual Participant, 4) Independent Thinker, 5) Compromiser.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Tradition Balance Style is Integrator, indicating you harmoniously blend both your and your partner's family religious traditions.

title: Religious Identity Style
research: Grounded in identity theory and research on maintaining religious identity in relationships
description: Assesses how couples support each other's religious identity while building a shared relationship identity

questions.question: How do you prefer to share your religious beliefs with your partner?
options: I love discussing and exploring new spiritual ideas together.
I prefer to listen and support my partner's beliefs.
I actively participate in religious activities and invite them to join.
I keep my beliefs private and only share when necessary.
I often feel unsure about how to integrate our beliefs.

questions.question: When planning holidays, how do you incorporate your religious practices?
options: We plan activities that align with both of our religious practices.
I respect my partner's practices and adjust my plans accordingly.
I take the lead in ensuring our religious traditions are observed.
I don't usually incorporate specific religious practices.
I struggle to find a balance between our religious traditions.

questions.question: How important is it for you to practice your religion together with your partner?
options: Very important, I seek to share and grow spiritually together.
Somewhat important, I'm open but not demanding.
Important, I enjoy leading joint religious activities.
Not very important, I prefer individual practices.
I find it challenging to align our religious practices.

questions.question: How do you handle differences in religious beliefs within your relationship?
options: We openly discuss and find common ground.
I respect our differences and avoid conflict.
I try to bridge the gap by introducing my beliefs.
I keep our religious differences separate from the relationship.
I often feel conflicted and uncertain about how to proceed.

questions.question: In everyday life, how do you express your religious identity?
options: I incorporate religious practices into our daily routines.
I support my partner's religious expressions without imposing mine.
I actively display and share my religious identity.
I keep my religious expressions personal and private.
I'm unsure how to express my religious identity alongside my partner's.

questions.question: When making major life decisions, how does your religion influence you?
options: I involve my religious beliefs as a key factor in decisions.
I consider my partner's beliefs alongside my own.
I primarily follow my religious guidelines in decisions.
I make decisions independently of religious considerations.
I feel torn between different religious perspectives when deciding.

questions.question: How do you celebrate religious milestones as a couple?
options: We celebrate them together, honoring both our traditions.
I support my partner's celebrations and participate as needed.
I take the initiative to celebrate our religious milestones.
We have minimal religious celebrations together.
I find it difficult to celebrate religious milestones jointly.

questions.question: How open are you to learning about your partner's religious practices?
options: Very open, I enjoy learning and integrating their practices.
Somewhat open, I'm willing to learn at a comfortable pace.
I'm interested in learning more about their religious practices.
I'm hesitant but try to understand their beliefs.
I'm reluctant to engage with their religious practices.

questions.question: When facing a moral dilemma, how do your religious beliefs guide you?
options: I consult my religious teachings to find a solution.
I consider both my and my partner's beliefs in resolving the dilemma.
I follow my own religious guidelines primarily.
I rely more on personal values than religious ones.
I'm unsure how to incorporate religion into resolving dilemmas.

questions.question: How do you view the role of religion in your long-term relationship goals?
options: Religion is central to our shared future plans.
Religion plays a supportive role in our long-term goals.
I see religion as a personal aspect, not central to our goals.
I prefer to keep religious beliefs separate from our future planning.
I find it challenging to align long-term goals with religious beliefs.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following religious identity styles: 1) Supportive Integrator, 2) Respectful Harmonizer, 3) Active Advocate, 4) Independent Preserver, 5) Conflicted Navigator.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Religious Identity Style is Supportive Integrator, indicating you actively work to integrate both partners' religious identities harmoniously in the relationship.

title: Spiritual Alignment Type
research: Based on spiritual development research and studies on supporting partner's religious journey
description: This theme measures how partners support each other's spiritual growth and religious exploration, even when paths differ, fostering mutual respect and understanding.

questions.question: When your partner shares their spiritual beliefs, how do you respond?
options: I show genuine interest and ask questions to understand better.
I listen respectfully without feeling the need to discuss further.
I share my own beliefs to find common ground.
I support them quietly without engaging in conversation.
I feel unsure how to respond and might change the subject.

questions.question: How do you incorporate your partner's spiritual practices into your daily life?
options: I actively participate and make it a shared activity.
I respect their practices and allow them space to engage alone.
I find ways to adapt my own practices to include theirs.
I support them by encouraging their participation.
I struggle to find ways to integrate their practices.

questions.question: When celebrating religious holidays, how do you prefer to approach it?
options: Celebrate together and participate in each other's traditions.
Respectfully acknowledge each other's holidays separately.
Mix traditions to create a unique celebration together.
Support your partner's way of celebrating without participating myself.
Feel conflicted and unsure how to celebrate appropriately.

questions.question: How do you handle discussions about spirituality with your partner during disagreements?
options: Use spirituality as a way to find common understanding.
Keep spiritual discussions separate from disagreements.
Seek to understand each other's spiritual perspectives to resolve conflicts.
Avoid bringing up spirituality during disagreements.
Feel overwhelmed and avoid discussing spirituality altogether.

questions.question: In what ways do you support your partner's desire to explore new spiritual practices?
options: Encourage and join them in exploring new practices.
Provide them with the resources they need to explore.
Respect their exploration even if I choose not to participate.
Offer emotional support while they explore on their own.
Feel hesitant and unsure how to support their exploration.

questions.question: How do you approach learning about your partner's religious background?
options: Actively seek out information and engage in discussions.
Show interest when they choose to share their background.
Respect their background without actively trying to learn more.
Support them by attending related events or services if asked.
Feel indifferent and prefer not to delve into their background.

questions.question: When your partner makes important spiritual decisions, how do you support them?
options: Participate and offer input when appropriate.
Respect their decisions and provide encouragement.
Discuss how their decisions impact both of us.
Offer practical support to help them follow through.
Feel unsure how to support their decisions effectively.

questions.question: How do you express respect for your partner's differing spiritual beliefs?
options: Celebrate the differences and find ways to blend our beliefs.
Acknowledge and honor their beliefs without comparison.
Discuss our differences to better understand each other.
Support their beliefs through actions and words.
Feel the need to reconcile our differences on my own.

questions.question: How do you integrate spirituality into your relationship goals?
options: Align our spiritual goals and work towards them together.
Respectfully maintain individual spiritual goals alongside shared ones.
Find common spiritual goals that we can pursue as a couple.
Support each other's spiritual goals while keeping them separate.
Struggle to find a balance between individual and shared spiritual goals.

questions.question: When faced with spiritual challenges, how do you handle them in your relationship?
options: Work together to find spiritual solutions and support each other.
Individually seek solutions while providing mutual support.
Discuss the challenges openly to find common ground.
Support each other through actions and understanding.
Feel overwhelmed and find it difficult to address the challenges together.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Spiritual Alignment Types: 1) Supportive Explorer, 2) Respectful Listener, 3) Harmonious Integrator, 4) Independent Seeker, 5) Balanced Mediator.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Spiritual Alignment Type is Supportive Explorer, indicating you actively encourage and engage in your partner's spiritual growth.

title: Community Integration Style
research: Based on social network theory and research on managing religious community relationships.
description: Discover how you approach integrating different religious communities into your social life. This quiz helps you understand your style of building inclusive and harmonious social networks.

questions.question: When attending religious events, how do you decide which ones to go to?
options: I attend a variety of events to experience different traditions.
I choose events that resonate most with my personal beliefs.
I balance attending events from multiple traditions.
I prefer to attend only my own religious events.
I rarely attend religious events and prefer to observe from a distance.

questions.question: How do you handle differing religious beliefs within your social circle?
options: I actively engage and participate in discussions about different beliefs.
I seek out friendships with similar religious beliefs.
I respect differences and find common ground.
I maintain my own beliefs and keep a distance from differing ones.
I avoid conversations about religion altogether.

questions.question: When introducing your partner to your religious community, what is your approach?
options: I enthusiastically involve them in various community activities.
I introduce them to key events that are most meaningful to me.
I ensure they feel comfortable and participate at their own pace.
I introduce them only to my close-knit group.
I prefer not to involve them in religious community activities.

questions.question: How do you build friendships within different religious communities?
options: I join multiple groups and actively participate in activities.
I focus on a few communities that align with my interests.
I engage with different communities while maintaining my primary focus.
I stick to my own community and rarely engage with others.
I observe and learn without actively participating.

questions.question: When planning social events, how do you incorporate diverse religious traditions?
options: I include a variety of traditions to celebrate diversity.
I incorporate elements from my preferred traditions.
I find a middle ground that respects multiple traditions.
I focus solely on my own traditions.
I keep religious traditions out of social events.

questions.question: How do you respond when a religious community invites you to participate in their activities?
options: I eagerly accept and participate in multiple activities.
I attend the most interesting or relevant activities.
I participate selectively, based on my schedule and interest.
I attend only a few activities that align closely with my beliefs.
I politely decline most invitations.

questions.question: How important is it for you to share the same religious beliefs as your friends?
options: Very important; I prefer diverse beliefs among friends.
Somewhat important; shared beliefs are a plus.
Moderately important; it's one of many factors.
Not very important; beliefs are personal.
Not important at all; I value other aspects of friendship.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements about religious practices with your partner?
options: I discuss and explore different practices together.
I respect their practices and expect them to respect mine.
I seek compromises that honor both practices.
I maintain my practices without much discussion.
I avoid discussing religious practices to prevent conflict.

questions.question: When traveling or visiting new places, how do you incorporate your religious practices?
options: I seek out local religious communities to engage with.
I follow my regular practices regardless of the location.
I adapt my practices to fit the local customs when possible.
I maintain my practices privately without seeking local engagement.
I rarely practice religion while traveling.

questions.question: How do you feel about participating in interfaith activities?
options: I love and actively seek out interfaith activities.
I participate in interfaith activities that interest me.
I am open to interfaith activities if they are inclusive.
I participate only if it doesn't conflict with my beliefs.
I prefer not to engage in interfaith activities.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following community integration patterns: 1) Inclusive Connector, 2) Selective Integrator, 3) Harmonious Balancer, 4) Independent Navigator, 5) Reserved Observer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Community Integration Style is Inclusive Connector, indicating you actively seek to engage with various religious communities and build diverse social networks.

title: Belief Change Adaptation Style
research: Grounded in research on religious transitions and relationship adaptation, this test explores how individuals handle changes in religious beliefs or practices within a relationship.
description: Religion can play a significant role in relationships. Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Belief Change Adaptation Style and understand how you navigate spiritual transitions with your partner!

questions.question: When you encounter a new religious perspective, how do you typically react?
options: I'm excited to learn and incorporate new ideas.
I prefer to stick to my existing beliefs.
I look for ways to integrate it with my current beliefs.
I tend to avoid the topic to keep peace.
I feel unsure and conflicted about how to proceed.

questions.question: If your partner decides to explore a different faith, you:
options: Encourage them and join them in their exploration.
Express concerns and emphasize your own beliefs.
Find a middle ground that respects both views.
Stay silent to avoid arguments.
Experience stress and uncertainty about the change.

questions.question: How do you handle religious disagreements with your partner?
options: Seek to understand their viewpoint fully.
Assert your own beliefs firmly.
Work together to find a compromise.
Change the subject to avoid conflict.
Feel overwhelmed and unsure of how to address it.

questions.question: When planning holidays or religious events, you:
options: Incorporate traditions from both beliefs.
Stick to your own traditions exclusively.
Alternate between each other's traditions.
Agree to follow one person's tradition to keep harmony.
Feel anxious about how to handle the differences.

questions.question: How do you view the role of religion in your relationship?
options: A dynamic and evolving aspect that can grow together.
A fixed part of who I am that shouldn't change.
An area where we can blend our beliefs.
A secondary aspect that doesn't need to be discussed much.
A complex issue that often causes me concern.

questions.question: When discussing future plans, how do religious beliefs factor in?
options: We openly discuss and align our beliefs for the future.
I prioritize my beliefs and expect my partner to respect them.
We negotiate and find a balance that works for both.
We avoid detailed discussions to prevent disagreements.
I worry about potential conflicts arising from differing beliefs.

questions.question: If you decide to change your religious practices, you:
options: Share your new practices and involve your partner.
Keep the change to yourself to avoid conflict.
Discuss how to incorporate the change together.
Make subtle changes without much discussion.
Feel uncertain and hesitant to make the change.

questions.question: How important is it for you and your partner to share the same religious beliefs?
options: Very important; it strengthens our connection.
Not very important; we respect each other's beliefs.
Somewhat important; we find ways to honor both.
Not important; we focus on other aspects of our relationship.
I'm conflicted about its importance and how to address it.

questions.question: When your partner expresses a desire to change their religious views, you:
options: Join them in exploring the new views.
Encourage them to stay with their original beliefs.
Support their journey while sharing your own perspective.
Avoid the topic to keep the peace.
Feel torn and unsure how to react.

questions.question: In moments of religious doubt or crisis, you:
options: Seek support and discuss it openly with your partner.
Rely solely on your personal beliefs to get through it.
Talk with your partner to find mutual support.
Keep your struggles private to avoid burdening your partner.
Feel overwhelmed and struggle to communicate your feelings.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the Belief Change Adaptation Styles: 1) Open Explorer, 2) Firm Resister, 3) Compromiser, 4) Peacekeeper, 5) Conflicted Adapter.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Belief Change Adaptation Style is Open Explorer, indicating you are open to understanding and integrating different beliefs in your relationship.

title: Adventure Comfort Style
research: Based on optimal arousal theory and research on shared novel experiences in relationship satisfaction.
description: Discover how you and your partner balance comfort and excitement when trying new things. This quiz helps you understand your adventure styles and how you support each other in stepping outside your comfort zones.

questions.question: When your partner suggests a spontaneous trip, how do you feel?
options: Excited and can't wait to explore.
Interested but prefer to plan the details.
Open to it if it's something we've both wanted to try.
A bit hesitant but willing to go along.
Uncomfortable and prefer to stay home.

questions.question: How do you react when faced with a new hobby your partner wants to try?
options: Eager to join and learn together.
Willing to try but need some guidance.
Happy to support them while pursuing it separately.
Agreeable but prefer sticking to familiar activities.
Prefer not to engage and stay with what you know.

questions.question: When planning a weekend, how much do you lean towards new experiences?
options: Most of the time, always seeking something new.
Often, but mix it with some familiar activities.
Sometimes, depending on our mood.
Rarely, prefer mostly familiar plans.
Almost never, stick to what you know and love.

questions.question: How do you feel about trying adventurous foods or cuisines?
options: Love it, always looking for new tastes.
Enjoy occasionally, but have preferred favorites.
Open to trying new things when interested.
Prefer familiar foods, but can be flexible.
Stick strictly to what you know and like.

questions.question: When your partner wants to watch a new movie genre, what's your response?
options: Excited to explore and discuss it afterwards.
Willing to watch with some initial curiosity.
Interested if it's something we've both agreed on.
Prefer to stick to familiar genres but might watch once in a while.
Prefer not to watch and choose something else.

questions.question: How do you approach learning a new skill together?
options: Dive in together with enthusiasm.
Take it step by step with clear goals.
Support each other while pursuing individual interests.
Join in but take turns leading the learning process.
Prefer to learn separately or not at all.

questions.question: When attending a social event, how likely are you to try new activities there?
options: Very likely, love participating in everything.
Likely, but balance with some familiar activities.
Moderately likely, depending on the activity.
Slightly likely, prefer observing more.
Unlikely, stick to what you're comfortable with.

questions.question: How do you feel about taking spontaneous risks in your relationship?
options: Thrilled, it keeps the relationship exciting.
Open, but prefer some level of planning.
Cautiously optimistic, assessing each situation.
Slightly apprehensive, prefer minimizing risks.
Uncomfortable, prefer to avoid risks altogether.

questions.question: What motivates you to try something new with your partner?
options: The excitement of discovering together.
The opportunity to grow and learn.
Sharing meaningful experiences.
Supporting your partner's interests.
Maintaining stability and comfort.

questions.question: When reflecting on past new experiences together, how do you feel?
options: Always excited and looking forward to more.
Happy with a good mix of new and old.
Appreciative of the memories we've created.
Content with mostly familiar experiences.
Prefer to focus on the comfortable routines.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Adventure Comfort Styles: 1) The Adventurer, 2) The Cautious Explorer, 3) The Balanced Partner, 4) The Comfort Seeker, 5) The Reserved.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Adventure Comfort Style is The Adventurer, indicating you thrive on new experiences and love exploring the unknown with your partner.

title: Novelty Integration Style
research: Grounded in self-expansion theory (Aron & Aron) and research on relationship boredom prevention
description: Keep the excitement alive in your relationship! This quiz measures how well you incorporate new experiences to prevent boredom and keep things fresh.

questions.question: When planning a weekend activity, what do you prefer to do?
options: Try something completely new and adventurous.
Mix a familiar activity with a new twist.
Stick to what we usually enjoy with a minor change.
Choose something safe and comfortable.
Let things happen naturally without specific plans.

questions.question: How do you feel about trying new hobbies together?
options: Excited and eager to explore together.
Interested, as long as it's not too risky.
Open, but prefer to keep a balance with old hobbies.
A bit hesitant but willing to give it a try.
Prefer to stick with our existing hobbies.

questions.question: When watching movies, you usually prefer:
options: Watching genres we've never tried before.
Exploring a mix of familiar and new genres.
Sticking mostly to our favorite genres with occasional variety.
Choosing genres we are comfortable with.
Watching what's easily available without much thought.

questions.question: How do you handle spontaneity in your relationship?

questions.question: What do you enjoy the most about reminiscing with your partner?

Collecting memorabilia that symbolize our moments together.
Transforming our memories into new fun activities.
Understanding how our past has shaped our present relationship.

questions.question: When you come across something that reminds you of your relationship, what do you do?

title: Competition Style Type

options: Winning gives me a great sense of accomplishment.
Winning together feels rewarding.

title: Goal Alignment Style

description: Discover how well you and your partner align your life goals! This fun quiz helps you evaluate your ability to create a unified vision for the future while honoring each other's individual aspirations.

questions.question: When setting financial goals, how do you prefer to approach them?

title: Financial Harmony Style
research: Grounded in behavioral economics and research on financial compatibility in relationships (Dew et al., 2012)
description: Assesses couples' compatibility in financial planning, spending habits, and long-term financial goals, including attitudes toward saving and investment.

questions.question: When unexpected expenses arise, how do you typically handle them?
options: I reassess my budget and make necessary adjustments.
I cover them immediately, even if it means cutting back elsewhere.

I look for investment opportunities or loans.
I feel stressed and unsure about how to handle them.

questions.question: How do you approach setting financial goals?
options: I create detailed plans with clear milestones.
I prefer to go with the flow and adjust as needed.
I prioritize saving and ensure goals are achievable.
I focus on growing wealth through various investments.
I often delay setting goals because I'm uncertain.

questions.question: When it comes to budgeting, what best describes your style?
options: I maintain a strict and organized budget.
I have a loose budget and enjoy flexibility.
I focus heavily on saving and minimizing expenses.
I allocate funds towards investments and financial growth.
I find budgeting challenging and inconsistent.

I often hesitate and struggle to make a decision.

To build a substantial savings for the future.

options: I create a detailed plan outlining the pros and cons before deciding.

options: I would research extensively and organize everything in advance.

options: Planning financially and ensuring we have the resources needed.

options: I create a comprehensive financial and lifestyle plan.

questions.question: When facing a major life transition, how do you support your partner?
options: I help by creating actionable plans and solutions.
I engage in open conversations to understand their needs.
I focus on emotional support and maintaining our connection.

questions.question: What is your primary concern when preparing for a major life change?
options: Ensuring that every detail is planned and accounted for.
Maintaining clear and open communication with my partner.

title: Future Planning Style

I prefer to plan my trips separately based on my availability.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Future Planning Styles: 1) Aligned Planner, 2) Flexible Scheduler, 3) Spontaneous Adventurer, 4) Cautious Organizer, 5) Independent Realist.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Future Planning Style is Aligned Planner, indicating you prefer detailed, coordinated plans with your partner for major life events.

title: Support Style Assessment
research: Based on social support theory and research on mutual support in long-term relationships, this assessment helps couples identify how they plan to support each other's future goals and aspirations, including career development and personal growth.
description: Curious about how you support your partner's dreams and goals? Take this lighthearted quiz to discover your Support Style and learn how you can better help each other achieve your aspirations!

questions.question: When your partner talks about their career goals, how do you respond?
options: Encourage them enthusiastically and offer positive feedback.
Help them create a step-by-step plan to achieve their goals.
Share your own experiences to motivate them.
Listen attentively and provide emotional support.
Ask questions to better understand their aspirations.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements about future plans?
options: Stay positive and look for common ground.
Discuss the pros and cons logically to find a solution.
Provide reassurance and boost their confidence.
Offer a listening ear to understand their perspective.
Seek compromise to ensure both feel supported.

questions.question: When your partner faces a setback, how do you help them recover?
options: Cheer them on and remind them of their strengths.
Help them devise a new strategy to overcome the obstacle.
Share motivational stories to lift their spirits.
Be there to listen and offer empathy.
Assist them in organizing their next steps.

questions.question: How do you celebrate your partner's achievements?
options: Give them heartfelt compliments and praise.
Plan a special activity to mark the occasion.
Encourage them to share their success with others.
Express your pride and happiness for them.
Help them set new goals to continue their progress.

questions.question: What do you do when your partner sets a new personal goal?
options: Show excitement and encourage them to pursue it.
Help them outline the steps needed to achieve it.
Motivate them by sharing your own goals and progress.
Provide a supportive environment for them to work on it.
Ask how you can assist in making their goal a reality.

questions.question: How do you approach financial planning for future goals?
options: Discuss openly and support each other's financial decisions.
Create a detailed financial plan together.
Motivate each other to save and invest wisely.
Provide emotional reassurance during financial discussions.
Collaborate to ensure both parties feel comfortable with the plan.

questions.question: When your partner needs time to focus on a project, how do you respond?
options: Encourage them and express confidence in their abilities.
Help manage other tasks to lighten their load.
Provide motivational support to keep them driven.
Respect their space and be available if they need to talk.
Offer practical assistance to help them stay on track.

questions.question: How do you support your partner's work-life balance?
options: Encourage them to pursue both career and personal interests.
Help organize schedules to manage time effectively.
Motivate them to maintain a healthy balance.
Provide emotional support when they feel overwhelmed.
Assist in setting boundaries to ensure they have personal time.

questions.question: What is your approach to learning new skills for the future?
options: Encourage exploring and trying new things together.
Help plan and prioritize which skills to learn.
Share resources and motivate each other to improve.
Listen and support their learning journey.
Assist in creating a learning schedule that fits both lifestyles.

questions.question: When discussing long-term aspirations, how do you engage?
options: Show enthusiasm and express belief in their dreams.
Help break down aspirations into actionable steps.
Provide motivational support to keep them inspired.
Listen carefully and offer emotional backing.
Collaborate to align your future plans together.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Support Styles: 1) Encouraging Supporter, 2) Strategic Planner, 3) Motivational Coach, 4) Emotional Supporter, 5) Collaborative Partner.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Support Style is Encouraging Supporter, indicating you thrive on uplifting your partner and boosting their confidence in their pursuits.

title: Risk Management Style
research: Derived from risk assessment psychology and research on couples' approaches to uncertainty, this test explores how you and your partner handle potential future challenges and unexpected life events.
description: Planning for the future together is essential for a strong relationship. This quiz helps you discover your individual risk management styles and how they complement each other, ensuring you're both prepared for whatever life throws your way!

questions.question: When thinking about financial investments, what is your approach?
options: I research extensively and plan strategically to minimize risks.
I prefer to make decisions on the spot based on how I feel.
I carefully weigh the pros and cons before investing.
I'm willing to take bold steps even if there's uncertainty.
I avoid making investments to keep things stable.

questions.question: How do you react when an unexpected expense arises?
options: I create a budget adjustment plan immediately.
I deal with it as it comes without prior planning.
I analyze the situation thoroughly before taking action.
I take it in stride, believing everything will work out.
I try to ignore it and hope it resolves itself.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle career changes or job loss?
options: I proactively seek new opportunities and plan ahead.
I adapt quickly and look for solutions in the moment.
I carefully assess my options before deciding on a path.
I remain optimistic and believe things will improve naturally.
I prefer to maintain the status quo and avoid making changes.

questions.question: When planning a major purchase, how do you proceed?
options: I set a detailed plan and save accordingly to mitigate financial risk.
I make the purchase based on current needs and feelings.
I evaluate all possible outcomes and make an informed decision.
I go for it confidently, trusting that it will benefit us.
I hesitate and often postpone the purchase to avoid potential issues.

questions.question: How do you approach health-related uncertainties, like potential illnesses?
options: I maintain a healthy lifestyle and have contingency plans in place.
I focus on enjoying the present and take care as needed.
I stay informed and prepare for different scenarios.
I stay positive and believe in positive outcomes.
I avoid thinking about it and hope for the best.

questions.question: How do you manage disagreements about future plans?
options: I work together to create a balanced plan that minimizes risks.
I address the disagreement calmly and find a quick resolution.
I discuss all possible implications before agreeing on a plan.
I stay optimistic and trust that we can handle it together.
I tend to avoid the disagreement and defer the decision.

questions.question: What is your strategy for saving for long-term goals like retirement?
options: I create a detailed savings plan and monitor it regularly.
I save as I can, without a strict plan.
I invest wisely after assessing all potential risks and benefits.
I save with confidence that our future will be secure.
I rely on existing funds and avoid thinking too far ahead.

questions.question: When faced with a potential move to a new city, how do you decide?
options: I research thoroughly and plan every aspect before deciding.
I decide based on how I feel about the opportunity.
I consider all factors and potential risks before making a choice.
I embrace the change with excitement and confidence.
I prefer to stay where things are familiar and avoid the move.

questions.question: How do you handle unexpected changes in your daily routine?
options: I quickly create a new plan to accommodate the change.
I go with the flow and adjust as needed.
I assess the impact thoroughly before adapting.
I remain positive and find the silver lining in the change.
I resist the change and stick to my usual routine.

questions.question: What is your approach to planning vacations or significant trips?
options: I plan every detail to ensure a smooth and risk-free trip.
I plan loosely and enjoy discovering things spontaneously.
I research and prepare for various scenarios that might occur.
I look forward to the adventure and handle issues as they arise.
I prefer not to plan too much to avoid potential stress.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following risk management styles: 1) Proactive Planner, 2) Reactive Adapter, 3) Cautious Analyzer, 4) Optimistic Risk-Taker, 5) Avoidant Secure.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Risk Management Style is Proactive Planner, indicating you prefer to anticipate and prepare for potential challenges in your relationship.

title: Legacy Style
research: Based on research on generativity (Erikson) and shared meaning in relationships
description: Discover your Legacy Style! This quiz helps you understand how you envision your long-term impact and shared legacy with your partner, covering aspects like family, community, and personal achievements.

questions.question: When you think about the impact you want to leave, what comes to mind first?
options: Raising a loving and close-knit family.
Contributing to the community through volunteering or activism.

Keeping plans flexible and seeing where life takes us.

questions.question: How important is it for you to involve your family in your long-term plans?
options: Extremely important; family is at the center of everything.
Important, but I also prioritize community involvement.
Somewhat important, but personal achievements take precedence.
I value a balance between family and other aspects.
It's not a priority; I prefer flexibility.

questions.question: In terms of community, what appeals to you the most?
options: Creating programs for families and children.
Starting or leading community initiatives.
Building a reputation in my professional field.
Engaging in various activities without a specific focus.
Participating spontaneously in community events.

questions.question: Which of these goals resonates with you the most?
options: Ensuring my children have the best opportunities.
Making a significant change in my community.
Reaching the pinnacle of my career.
Having a well-rounded life with multiple achievements.
Taking life as it comes and setting goals along the way.

questions.question: When planning for the future, what motivates you the most?
options: The thought of a happy family and future generations.
The desire to make a positive impact on society.
Achieving personal success and recognition.
Creating a meaningful and balanced life.
The excitement of new and unexpected opportunities.

questions.question: How do you view personal achievements in the context of your legacy?
options: They are essential and central to my legacy.
Important, but my community impact matters more.
My achievements define my legacy.
I value both equally for a balanced legacy.

questions.question: What role does work play in your long-term plans?
options: My work is primarily focused on supporting and growing my family.
I want my work to contribute significantly to the community.
I aim to excel and be recognized in my profession.
I seek a career that allows me to balance multiple aspects.
I'm open to different paths and opportunities as they come.

questions.question: How do you feel about setting specific long-term goals?
options: I prefer clear, family-oriented goals.
I like setting goals that benefit the community.
I focus on ambitious personal and professional goals.
I set goals in various areas to maintain balance.
I prefer not to set strict long-term goals.

questions.question: What brings you the most fulfillment when thinking about the future?
options: Seeing my family grow and succeed.
Seeing positive changes in my community.
Achieving my personal dreams and aspirations.
Having a fulfilling life across multiple areas.
Embracing the journey without fixed outcomes.

questions.question: How do you want to be remembered?
options: As someone who was a great parent and family member.
As a person who gave back to the community.
As a successful and influential professional.
As someone who achieved a balanced and meaningful life.
As a free spirit who lived life spontaneously.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Legacy Styles: 1) Family Builder, 2) Community Leader, 3) Achievement Seeker, 4) Balanced Achiever, 5) Flexibility Embracer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Legacy Style is Family Builder, indicating you prioritize creating a loving and supportive family as the foundation of your legacy.

title: Relationship Adaptability Style
research: Grounded in psychological flexibility research and studies on relationship resilience.
description: This quiz measures your ability to adapt future plans while maintaining relationship stability, including your openness to revising goals as circumstances change.

questions.question: When unexpected changes arise in your plans, how do you handle them?
options: I stick to the original plan no matter what.
I embrace the change and look for new opportunities.
I discuss with my partner to find a new plan together.
I carefully consider the change and adjust accordingly, but feel uneasy.
I resist the change and prefer to keep things as they were.

questions.question: How do you feel about setting long-term goals with your partner?
options: I prefer detailed and fixed long-term goals.
I'm open to adjusting our goals as needed.
I like to collaborate with my partner to set our goals.
I set goals but remain cautious about changes.
I find setting long-term goals stressful and prefer not to.

questions.question: When facing a setback in your plans, what is your typical response?
options: I get frustrated and try to fix the original plan.
I look for alternative solutions and move forward.
I work with my partner to overcome the setback together.
I take time to evaluate the situation before deciding.
I tend to give up and avoid dealing with it.

questions.question: How do you approach making significant life decisions with your partner?
options: I prefer to follow a structured decision-making process.
I am flexible and adapt my decisions based on circumstances.
I prefer to discuss and make decisions together.
I evaluate the risks carefully before deciding.
I find it difficult to make decisions and often avoid them.

questions.question: When new opportunities arise that affect your plans, how do you react?
options: I assess how they fit into our existing plans.
I seize the opportunity and adjust our plans accordingly.
I talk with my partner to decide the best course of action.
I weigh the pros and cons before making any changes.
I decline the opportunity to maintain our current plans.

questions.question: How do you feel about changing your daily routine for the sake of the relationship?
options: I prefer to keep my routine unchanged.
I'm open to changing the routine if it benefits us.
I like to discuss and agree on any changes with my partner.
I agree to changes but feel a bit uneasy about them.
I resist changing my routine and stick to what I know.

questions.question: When planning a vacation, how do you handle unexpected issues like weather changes?
options: I stick to the original itinerary regardless of the issues.
I adapt the plans to make the best of the situation.
I collaborate with my partner to find alternative activities.
I carefully adjust our plans to minimize the impact.

questions.question: How do you approach financial planning with your partner when circumstances change?
options: I stick to our financial plan no matter what.
I'm flexible and adjust our financial goals as needed.
I discuss and revise our financial plans together.
I cautiously modify our financial strategy to accommodate changes.
I avoid making changes and try to maintain the status quo.

questions.question: When one of you wants to pursue a new hobby or interest, how do you respond?
options: I prefer to continue with our current activities.
I support and adapt to the new interest enthusiastically.
I engage in new activities together with my partner.
I cautiously incorporate the new interest into our routine.
I feel uncomfortable and discourage the new interest.

questions.question: How do you handle moving to a new city or home together?
options: I focus on maintaining our original plans regardless of the move.
I embrace the move and see it as an exciting change.
I collaborate with my partner to make the move smooth.
I carefully plan and adjust our lives to accommodate the move.
I resist the move and prefer to stay where we are.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following adaptability styles: 1) Planner, 2) Flexible Adaptor, 3) Collaborative Adjuster, 4) Cautious Rescheduler, 5) Resistant to Change.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 2) most frequently, your Adaptability Style is Flexible Adaptor, indicating you are open to adjusting plans and embracing changes in your relationship.

Overcoming adversity and building resilience.

It motivates you to set and achieve goals as a couple.

options: Opening up immediately with detailed accounts.

options: Exciting adventures and spontaneous events.

Personal achievements and proud moments.
Deep, introspective experiences and thoughts.
Challenging times and how you overcame them.

Focusing on successes and accomplishments.
Sharing personal growth and insights gained.

options: It encourages us to continuously seek new adventures.

It drives us to achieve our goals and aspirations together.

It strengthens our ability to support each other through challenges.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Life Story Styles: 1) Adventurer, 2) Family-Oriented, 3) Achiever, 4) Reflective, 5) Resilient.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Life Story Style is Adventurer, indicating you value exciting experiences and seek new adventures in your relationship.

Ensure that both sides are heard and treated fairly.

Seek creative and novel solutions that break the mold.

questions.question: What motivates you to work hard?
options: Fulfilling your family's expectations and legacy.
Achieving personal excellence and self-improvement.
Making a positive impact on society and promoting fairness.

title: Dreams and Goals Style

description: Discover how you and your partner envision the future! This quiz helps you understand each other's hopes and dreams, fostering a sense of support and shared purpose in your relationship.

I reassess my plans and make necessary adjustments.
