Adapt easily to the new setup.
Feel uneasy and prefer things to remain unchanged.

questions.question: How do you prefer to spend time in shared spaces?
options: Dedicate specific times for joint activities.
Mix personal activities with shared ones naturally.
Plan activities together to use shared spaces.
Be spontaneous based on the moment's needs.
Keep personal and shared time separate as much as possible.

questions.question: How do you handle personal items in shared spaces?
options: Keep personal items in designated personal areas.
Integrate personal items with shared belongings.
Organize personal items in a way that complements shared spaces.
Store personal items flexibly based on current needs.
Limit personal items in shared spaces to maintain privacy.

questions.question: How important is it for you to have routines in shared living spaces?
options: Very important; I prefer structured routines.
Somewhat important; I like having some predictability.
Moderately important; open to flexible routines.
Slightly important; I adapt routines as needed.
Not important; I prefer spontaneous use of space.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following space harmony types: 1) Independent Planner, 2) Harmonious Integrator, 3) Collaborative Organizer, 4) Flexible Adapter, 5) Reserved Protector.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Living Space Harmony Type is Independent Planner, indicating you prefer distinct personal spaces and clear boundaries in your shared living environment.

title: Daily Rhythm Style
research: Grounded in circadian psychology and research on couples' daily routine compatibility
description: Assess how well your daily schedules, habits, and routines align with your partner's. Understand each other's sleep patterns and energy levels to create a harmonious living environment.

questions.question: What time do you usually wake up on weekdays?
options: Before 6 AM
Around 7-8 AM
Mid-morning, around 9-10 AM
Late morning to early afternoon
Varies greatly day by day

questions.question: How do you prefer to start your mornings?
options: With a structured routine and set activities
Jumping straight into work or daily tasks
Enjoying a relaxed breakfast and some leisure time
Engaging in physical exercise or outdoor activities
It depends on how I feel each day

questions.question: When do you feel most energetic during the day?
options: Early morning
Late morning
Early afternoon
Evening
Night

questions.question: How do you handle weekends compared to weekdays?
options: Maintain the same schedule as weekdays
Wake up a bit later but keep similar routines
Enjoy a mix of activities and relaxation
Prefer spontaneous plans without a set schedule
It varies greatly depending on my mood

questions.question: How important is it for you to have a consistent bedtime?
options: Very important, I stick to it strictly
Somewhat important, I try to keep it consistent
Not very important, I go to bed when I feel tired
I often change my bedtime based on my day
I have no set bedtime and it varies widely

questions.question: How do you prefer to organize your daily tasks?
options: With a detailed schedule and to-do list
With a general plan but flexible timing
I handle tasks as they come without strict planning
By prioritizing tasks and adjusting as needed
I rarely plan and prefer to be spontaneous

questions.question: How do you typically feel in the late evening?
options: Still full of energy, want to stay active
Starting to wind down but still active
Ready to relax and unwind
Prefer quiet and calm activities
Often too tired to engage in any activities

questions.question: How flexible are you with changes in your daily routine?
options: I prefer routines and find changes challenging
I can adapt to some changes without much difficulty
I handle changes fairly well and adjust accordingly
I enjoy variety and welcome changes in my routine
I thrive on unpredictability and dislike routines

questions.question: How do you manage your energy levels throughout the day?
options: I maintain high energy consistently with scheduled breaks
I have peaks and troughs but manage them well
My energy fluctuates and I take breaks as needed
I adapt my activities based on how I feel each moment
My energy levels are unpredictable and vary widely

questions.question: When living together, how do you prefer to coordinate daily activities?
options: With a shared schedule and planned activities
By discussing plans each morning
By having general guidelines but flexible plans
By going with the flow and planning as we go
I prefer not to coordinate and handle activities independently

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the daily rhythm styles: 1) Early Bird, 2) Morning Energizer, 3) Balanced Scheduler, 4) Flexible Adaptor, 5) Night Owl.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Daily Rhythm Style is Early Bird, indicating you prefer mornings and structured routines in your day.

title: Domestic Labor Style
research: Based on equity theory and research on household labor distribution in relationships
description: Measures how couples plan to divide household responsibilities and manage expectations for domestic tasks.

questions.question: When assigning household chores, how do you prefer to decide who does what?
options: We split everything equally, sharing all tasks.
We stick to traditional roles: I handle cooking and cleaning, while you manage payments and outdoor tasks.
We discuss and assign tasks based on our individual strengths and schedules.
I prefer you take on more tasks, and I contribute when I can.
We adjust tasks as needed, depending on our current priorities and circumstances.

questions.question: How do you feel about creating a chore schedule?
options: I think having a detailed schedule helps us stay organized and fair.
I prefer a traditional approach without a strict schedule.
I like to negotiate and decide tasks as we go.
I don't mind if the schedule is more flexible and less defined.
I feel overwhelmed by schedules and prefer to handle tasks spontaneously.

questions.question: What is your approach to cleaning up after meals?
options: We take turns washing dishes and cleaning the kitchen equally.
I usually take care of the dishes, while you handle other chores.
We decide together who will clean up based on our availability.
I let you handle the dishes more often, and I help when I can.
We clean up together in a flexible manner without a fixed routine.

questions.question: How do you handle unexpected household tasks, like a plumbing issue?
options: We both pitch in and handle it together to ensure it's done promptly.
I take the lead on handling such issues based on traditional responsibility.
We discuss who has the time and skills to manage the task effectively.
I rely on you to manage unexpected tasks while I assist when possible.
We adapt our approach based on the situation and urgency of the task.

questions.question: What is your preference for grocery shopping responsibilities?
options: We share the responsibility equally, taking turns each week.
I handle grocery shopping as part of my traditional role.
We decide together who goes based on our schedules each week.
I prefer you handle the grocery shopping, and I help with meal prep.
We switch roles as needed, depending on our availability and preferences.

questions.question: How do you feel about taking care of household finances?
options: We manage finances together, ensuring transparency and equal participation.
I take the lead on finances, handling bills and budgeting.
We collaborate and divide financial responsibilities based on our strengths.
I let you manage the finances, and I support by contributing where I can.
We handle financial tasks flexibly, adapting to changes as they come.

questions.question: When it comes to organizing shared spaces, like the living room, what's your approach?
options: We both participate equally in keeping shared spaces tidy and organized.
I take charge of organizing shared spaces as part of my traditional role.
We plan and divide organizing tasks based on our individual strengths.
I rely on you to organize shared spaces, and I help when needed.
We organize shared spaces together in a flexible and spontaneous manner.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle laundry duties?
options: We split laundry tasks equally, each taking care of our own and shared items.
I usually handle the laundry as part of my traditional responsibilities.
We decide together who does the laundry based on our weekly schedules.
I prefer you take care of the laundry, and I assist with ironing or folding.
We manage laundry duties flexibly, adjusting as needed each week.

questions.question: What is your strategy for meal planning and cooking?
options: We plan and cook meals together, sharing responsibilities equally.
I primarily handle meal planning and cooking as part of my role.
We alternate meal planning and cooking based on our availability.
I let you take the lead on cooking, and I help with prep or cleanup.
We cook meals together in a flexible way, adapting to our schedules.

questions.question: How do you approach taking care of pets or household animals?
options: We share all pet care responsibilities equally.
I take the main responsibility for pet care in line with traditional roles.
We divide pet care tasks based on our individual strengths and schedules.
I rely on you to handle most of the pet care, and I assist when possible.
We manage pet care duties flexibly, depending on our current situation.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following household labor division styles: 1) Equal Sharers, 2) Traditional Roles, 3) Negotiated Partners, 4) Dependent Contributors, 5) Flexible Adaptors.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Domestic Labor Style is Equal Sharers, indicating you prefer an equal distribution of household tasks.

title: Financial Planning Style
research: Derived from financial psychology research and studies on money management in cohabiting relationships.
description: Discover how you approach managing money with your partner! This quiz will help you understand your financial habits and preferences, making cohabitation smoother and more harmonious.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle household budget planning?
options: Create a detailed budget and stick to it meticulously.
Have a general budget but allow some flexibility for spontaneous expenses.
Focus on saving as much as possible without strict budgeting.
Work together to create a shared budget that satisfies both of us.
Let each person manage their own expenses independently.

questions.question: When it comes to saving money, you usually:
options: Set specific savings goals and regularly contribute to them.
Save when you can, but it's not a strict priority.
Prioritize saving and avoid unnecessary spending.
Collaborate with your partner to set and achieve savings goals together.
Find it challenging to save and prefer to enjoy spending.

questions.question: How do you react when unexpected expenses arise?
options: Immediately adjust the budget to accommodate the expense.
Find a way to cover it without major changes to the budget.
Use savings to handle the unexpected cost.
Discuss with your partner to decide the best course of action.
Feel stressed and unsure how to handle it.

questions.question: What is your attitude towards investing money?
options: Research thoroughly and make informed investment decisions.
Invest occasionally when you feel confident about it.
Prefer to keep money in safe savings accounts rather than investing.
Discuss investment options and make decisions together with your partner.
Avoid investing and leave it to others to manage.

questions.question: How do you feel about tracking daily expenses?
options: Essential and regularly track every expense.
Useful but not necessary to track every single one.
Prefer not to track and keep finances simple.
Track some expenses and discuss big ones with your partner.
Find tracking expenses tedious and avoid it.

questions.question: When making a large purchase, you:
options: Research extensively before deciding.
Consider it carefully but make the decision on your own.
Prefer to save up before making any large purchases.
Discuss and agree on the purchase with your partner.
Make the purchase impulsively if you really want it.

questions.question: How do you approach financial disagreements with your partner?
options: Address them directly and work towards a solution.
Try to resolve them quickly without prolonged discussion.
Avoid disagreements by sticking strictly to your own plan.
Collaborate to find a compromise that works for both.
Feel uncomfortable and let the issue go unresolved.

questions.question: Your approach to debt management is to:
options: Pay off debts as quickly as possible with a clear plan.
Manage debts while maintaining some financial flexibility.
Minimize taking on debt and focus on avoiding it.
Work with your partner to create a joint debt repayment strategy.
Feel overwhelmed by debt and struggle to manage it.

questions.question: How do you prioritize financial goals?
options: Set clear, prioritized goals and focus on achieving them one by one.
Have a mix of short-term and long-term goals without strict prioritization.
Prioritize saving for the future above all else.
Align financial goals with your partner to ensure mutual priorities.
Have difficulty setting and prioritizing financial goals.

questions.question: When budgeting for leisure activities, you:
options: Allocate a specific amount and plan activities within that budget.
Budget loosely and allow for spontaneous spending on fun.
Prefer to minimize spending on leisure to save more.
Decide together with your partner how much to spend on leisure.
Often overspend on leisure activities without planning.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following financial planning styles: 1) Planner, 2) Flexible Spender, 3) Saver, 4) Collaborative Partner, 5) Spontaneous Spender.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Financial Planning Style is Planner, indicating you prefer organized and detailed financial management in your relationship.

title: Boundary Setting Style
research: Based on psychological boundary theory and research on maintaining individuality in cohabiting relationships
description: This quiz helps evaluate how you establish and maintain healthy boundaries while sharing living space, including social boundaries.

questions.question: When you and your partner decide on personal time, how do you prefer to handle it?
options: I like having a set schedule for personal time.
I prefer to decide spontaneously based on how I feel.
I discuss with my partner each time to agree on personal time.
I usually go with what my partner prefers for personal time.
I need a lot of personal time and may feel overwhelmed if not respected.

questions.question: How do you approach sharing household chores with your partner?
options: I prefer to have a clear division of chores and stick to it.
I'm open to switching chores based on our moods or schedules.
I like to discuss and decide together which chores to do.
I often take on extra chores to keep the peace.
I avoid discussing chores and let my partner handle them.

questions.question: How do you feel about personal space in your shared living environment?
options: I need clearly defined personal spaces in the home.
I'm flexible about sharing spaces as long as we're both comfortable.
I enjoy having shared spaces and collaborating on how to use them.
I prioritize my partner's need for space over my own.
I feel uncomfortable if personal spaces aren't strictly maintained.

questions.question: When it comes to socializing at home, what is your preference?
options: I prefer to have scheduled times for guests and social activities.
I'm open to spontaneous social gatherings whenever we feel like it.
I like to discuss and decide together when to host guests.
I often accommodate my partner's desire to have guests over.
I avoid having guests over to maintain peace.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements over household decisions?
options: I address them directly and work towards a mutual agreement.
I remain flexible and willing to compromise as needed.
I engage in discussions to find a solution that works for both.
I tend to give in to avoid conflict.
I avoid addressing the disagreement altogether.

questions.question: How do you manage your personal hobbies and interests in a shared home?
options: I clearly allocate time and space for my personal hobbies.
I integrate my hobbies with household activities flexibly.
I discuss and arrange how to pursue hobbies together.
I often pause my hobbies to support my partner's interests.
I keep my hobbies secret to avoid tension.

questions.question: What is your approach to financial management in cohabitation?
options: I prefer to have a detailed and separate financial plan.
I'm flexible and adjust financial contributions as needed.
I like to discuss and decide financial matters together.
I accommodate my partner's financial management style.
I avoid discussing finances to prevent conflict.

questions.question: How do you handle privacy in a shared living space?
options: I maintain strict privacy boundaries and expect the same.
I'm flexible with privacy as long as mutual respect is present.
I collaborate with my partner to define our privacy needs.
I often sacrifice my privacy to accommodate my partner's needs.
I ignore privacy boundaries to avoid confrontation.

questions.question: How do you feel about making individual decisions in a shared household?
options: I prefer to make my own decisions independently.
I'm open to making individual decisions with flexibility.
I like to discuss and reach consensus on decisions together.
I tend to follow my partner's lead in decision-making.
I avoid making decisions to maintain harmony.

questions.question: How do you manage your digital boundaries (e.g., privacy on devices, use of shared accounts)?
options: I have clear rules about digital privacy and expect the same.
I'm flexible and adjust digital boundaries as needed.
I communicate with my partner to set mutual digital boundaries.
I often let my partner manage digital boundaries to keep peace.
I avoid setting digital boundaries to prevent disputes.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following boundary setting styles: 1) Assertive, 2) Flexible, 3) Collaborative, 4) Accommodating, 5) Avoidant.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Boundary Setting Style is Assertive, indicating you clearly communicate and uphold your personal boundaries in the relationship.

title: Social Harmony Style
research: Based on social network theory and research on managing relationships with friends and family while cohabiting. This test helps couples understand how to balance their social lives and hosting responsibilities in their shared home.
description: Moving in together means blending not just your lives, but also your social circles. Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Social Harmony Style and learn how to create a balanced and harmonious home environment!

questions.question: When a friend wants to visit, how do you feel about hosting them at your shared home?
options: Excited and love being entertaining hosts.
Happy to host but prefer having a set schedule.

questions.question: How do you manage time spent with friends versus time with your partner?
options: Balance equally, ensuring both get quality time.
Prioritize partner but make time for important friendships.

Let the situation decide without strict planning.
Struggle to find a balance and often feel guilty.

questions.question: When planning a social event at home, what role do you usually take?
options: Take the lead in organizing and coordinating.
Help with specific tasks like invitations or setup.

Support your partner in their organizing efforts.
Feel stressed and prefer to avoid organizing.

questions.question: How do you handle hosting family gatherings in your shared space?
options: Love hosting and enjoy bringing family together.

Take turns choosing activities based on preferences.
One partner usually decides while the other adapts.

Introduce them casually during regular meetups.
Prefer one-on-one introductions to larger groups.

options: Share tasks equally to ensure smooth hosting.
Allocate specific roles based on strengths.
One partner handles most responsibilities.
Organize tasks flexibly as needed for each event.

questions.question: What do you do to ensure your home remains a balanced space for both partners and guests?
options: Create dedicated areas for socializing and private time.
Set clear boundaries and communicate them effectively.
Adapt the environment based on the type of gathering.

Struggle to maintain balance and often feel stressed.

options: Excited and eager to build a large, integrated social circle.
Happy to integrate while maintaining your own traditions.
Prefer to keep social circles separate to avoid complications.
Supportive but prefer gradual integration.
Anxious and hesitant about mixing social circles.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Social Harmony Styles: 1) The Host, 2) The Planner, 3) The Social Balancer, 4) The Supportive Partner, 5) The Reserved Integrator.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Social Harmony Style is The Host, indicating you thrive on entertaining and bringing people together in your shared home.

title: Living Harmony Style
research: Derived from research on lifestyle congruence and its impact on relationship satisfaction, this quiz assesses how well your living habits, cleanliness standards, and lifestyle preferences align with your partner's for a harmonious cohabitation.
description: Moving in together is a big step! Take this lighthearted quiz to discover your Living Harmony Style and see how well your daily habits and preferences mesh. It's a fun way to prepare for cohabitation and ensure a smooth living experience together.

questions.question: How do you prefer to organize shared living spaces?
options: I like everything neatly arranged and in its place.
A bit of order, but I'm okay with some mess.
I prefer a relaxed and clutter-free environment.
I enjoy decorating and occasionally rearranging things.

questions.question: How often do you like to clean your living space?
options: Daily – I like to keep things spotless at all times.
A few times a week – regular but not daily.

options: I make detailed meal plans and shop accordingly every week.
I have a general idea and adjust as needed while shopping.
I prefer spontaneous cooking and shop as I go.
I like to cook together and decide meals with my partner.

options: I like to create a detailed budget and track every expense.
I prefer a monthly financial review to stay on track.
I handle my finances independently and keep them separate.

options: Very important – I need a lot of alone time.

Less important – I prefer spending most of my time with my partner.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle household chores?
options: I like a clear division of chores and stick to it.
We create a chore schedule together and follow it.
I take the lead and manage most of the chores.

questions.question: What's your ideal weekend routine when living together?
options: Having a structured plan with specific activities.
Balancing planned activities with some free time.
Spontaneous outings and going with the flow.
Spending quality time together with a mix of activities.
Relaxing at home and enjoying each other's company.

questions.question: How do you deal with differences in dietary preferences or restrictions?
options: I plan separate meals to accommodate our preferences.
We find common meals that satisfy both of us.
I'm flexible and willing to adapt to my partner's needs.
We take turns cooking meals that cater to each other.
I prioritize my partner's dietary needs over mine.

questions.question: How do you feel about having guests or hosting gatherings at home?
options: I love hosting and often have guests over.
I enjoy occasional gatherings with close friends and family.
I prefer keeping our home private with few or no guests.
I'm comfortable with guests as long as it's planned in advance.

options: I have a strict bedtime and prefer quiet evenings.

title: Cohabitation Resilience Style
research: Based on crisis management research and studies on couples' resilience during challenging times.
description: Discover how you and your partner prepare for unexpected situations and handle emergencies together. This quiz assesses your resilience styles to help you plan effectively for your shared living arrangement.

questions.question: When an unexpected bill arrives, how do you handle it?
options: Immediately create a budget to accommodate the expense.
Adapt by cutting back on other expenses temporarily.
Discuss it openly with your partner to find a solution together.
Handle it on your own to minimize stress on your partner.
Stay calm and look for the best way to manage it without conflict.

questions.question: If a major appliance breaks down at home, what is your first step?
options: Research the best repair options and schedule it quickly.
Find an alternative solution until it can be fixed.
Talk to your partner about the best course of action.
Take care of the repair yourself without involving others.
Remain relaxed and handle the situation smoothly.

questions.question: How do you prepare for potential natural disasters?
options: Create a detailed emergency plan and checklist.
Stay flexible and adjust plans as needed.
Ensure open communication with your partner about plans.
Handle preparations independently to avoid burdening your partner.
Maintain a calm demeanor and support each other during preparations.

questions.question: When making a big financial decision, what do you do?
options: Analyze all possible outcomes and plan meticulously.
Be ready to adapt the decision if circumstances change.
Discuss thoroughly with your partner before deciding.
Make the decision on your own to avoid disagreement.
Approach the decision calmly and ensure it benefits both.

questions.question: In case of a health emergency, how do you respond?
options: Have a clear plan and necessary contacts ready.
Stay adaptable and handle the situation as it unfolds.
Communicate clearly with your partner to manage the emergency together.
Take charge of the situation independently.
Stay calm and provide mutual support throughout the process.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements on household responsibilities?
options: Create a structured plan to divide tasks efficiently.
Stay flexible and adjust responsibilities as needed.
Discuss openly with your partner to find a fair solution.
Manage your responsibilities on your own without involving your partner.
Maintain a peaceful approach and support each other's efforts.

questions.question: When faced with a sudden change in work schedule, what do you do?

Adapt your schedule to fit the new circumstances.
Talk to your partner to adjust plans together.
Handle the change on your own to minimize impact on your partner.
Stay calm and find a balanced way to manage the new schedule.

questions.question: How do you approach major life decisions, like moving to a new city?
options: Plan every detail in advance and consider all possible scenarios.
Be open to changing your plans based on new information.
Discuss extensively with your partner to reach a mutual decision.
Make the decision independently to ensure it aligns with your preferences.
Approach the decision calmly and support each other's viewpoints.

questions.question: If a friend or family member causes stress in your relationship, how do you handle it?
options: Set clear boundaries and communicate them effectively.
Adapt your interactions to reduce stress.
Discuss the issue with your partner to find a joint solution.
Manage the situation on your own to protect your relationship.
Stay calm and work together to address the stress.

questions.question: How do you ensure your living space remains safe and comfortable during emergencies?
options: Regularly update and review safety plans and equipment.
Stay flexible and make necessary adjustments as situations arise.
Coordinate with your partner to maintain a safe environment.
Take responsibility for safety preparations on your own.
Remain calm and work together to ensure a comfortable living space.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the Cohabitation Resilience Styles: 1) Planner, 2) Adaptable Responder, 3) Communicative Coordinator, 4) Independent Solver, 5) Calm Mediator.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Cohabitation Resilience Style is Planner, indicating you prefer to create detailed plans to handle unexpected situations.

title: Growth Space Style

description: Discover your unique Growth Space Style and learn how you and your partner can support each other's personal growth and independence while sharing a living space.

options: I set aside specific times for my hobbies and interests.
I like having a flexible schedule that allows spontaneous activities.

Look for a halfway point that satisfies both.
Collaborate to find a solution that works for both of us.

Spending quality time together after a compliment.
They help you by doing something nice alongside the compliment.
A warm hug or a touch when they compliment you.

questions.question: When you're stressed, what gesture from your partner helps you the most?
options: They give you reassuring words and affirm your feelings.
They surprise you with a small gift to brighten your day.
They make time to listen and talk things through with you.
They take care of some of your responsibilities to lighten your load.
They offer a comforting hug or hold your hand.

questions.question: How do you naturally express your love?
options: By expressing your feelings and giving compliments.
By giving gifts that show you care.
By spending quality time and creating memories together.
By doing things that help and support your partner.
By showing physical affection like hugs and kisses.

questions.question: What makes you feel most connected to your partner?
options: Having meaningful and heartfelt conversations.
Receiving thoughtful presents that reflect your interests.
Engaging in fun and enjoyable activities together.
Your partner helping you with tasks or chores.
Sharing physical intimacy and closeness.

questions.question: How do you like to celebrate special occasions?
options: By exchanging heartfelt words and expressing love.
By giving and receiving meaningful gifts.
By spending uninterrupted quality time together.
By performing acts that make the day easier and special.
By being physically affectionate throughout the celebration.

questions.question: When your partner surprises you, what type of surprise do you appreciate most?
options: A sincere and heartfelt message or note.
A thoughtful gift that shows they understand you.
Planning a special day or activity for just the two of you.
Helping out with something important to you unexpectedly.
A spontaneous hug or affectionate gesture.

questions.question: What role do you prefer during romantic moments?
options: Expressing your feelings openly and honestly.
Presenting thoughtful gifts or tokens of affection.
Creating and sharing memorable experiences together.
Taking initiative to make things easier and nicer for your partner.
Being physically close and affectionate.

questions.question: How do you like to resolve misunderstandings with your partner?
options: Talking it out and verbally expressing your feelings.
Offering a meaningful gift to show you care.
Spending time together to reconnect and understand each other.
Performing a kind act to demonstrate your commitment.
Using physical touch to comfort and reconcile.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of Gary Chapman's Five Love Languages: 1) Words of Affirmation, 2) Gifts, 3) Quality Time, 4) Acts of Service, and 5) Physical Touch.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if most of your answers are 1), your primary love language is Words of Affirmation, meaning you feel most loved when you hear kind and encouraging words from your partner.

title: Emotional Awareness Type
research: Based on emotional intelligence research and Mayer-Salovey's EI framework for understanding emotions
description: Evaluates partners' ability to identify and understand their own emotional states, including awareness of emotional triggers and patterns

questions.question: When you start feeling anxious, what's the first thing you do to address it?
options: Take a moment to reflect on what's causing the anxiety.
Talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling.
Engage in a distraction, like watching TV or reading.
Ignore it and hope it goes away on its own.
Act impulsively to try and change the situation.

questions.question: How do you typically recognize your own emotions throughout the day?
options: I regularly check in with myself to understand my feelings.
I often realize how I feel when something specific happens.
My emotions usually come to me without much thought.
I sometimes struggle to identify what I'm feeling.
I rarely think about my emotions unless there's a strong reaction.

questions.question: When experiencing a strong emotion, how do you usually respond?
options: Analyze why you're feeling this way and what triggers it.
Express your emotions to your partner or a friend.
Channel your emotions into a creative or physical activity.
Suppress your emotions to avoid conflict or discomfort.
Let your emotions take over and react immediately.

questions.question: How do you handle emotional surprises or unexpected feelings?
options: Reflect on the emotions to understand their origin.
Share the feelings with someone you trust right away.
Distract yourself until you feel better.
Feel overwhelmed and unsure how to proceed.
Respond impulsively based on the emotion.

questions.question: When something upsets you, what's your usual approach to dealing with it?
options: Take time to process your feelings before addressing the issue.
Discuss your feelings openly with your partner.
Find a way to lighten the mood or make yourself laugh.
Keep your feelings to yourself to avoid burdening others.
Act out of emotion without thinking about the consequences.

questions.question: How do you increase your emotional awareness in your daily life?
options: Practice mindfulness or meditation regularly.
Journal about your feelings and experiences.
Engage in activities that make you feel good.
Rely on others to understand your emotions.
Don't pay much attention to your emotional states.

questions.question: When reflecting on past conflicts, how do you view your emotional responses?
options: I understand how my emotions influenced the outcome.
I recognize my emotions but struggle to analyze them.
I mostly remember the emotions but not the reasons behind them.
I find it hard to recall my emotional state during conflicts.
I usually deny having strong emotions during conflicts.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with expressing your emotions?
options: Very comfortable; I express my feelings openly.
Comfortable most of the time, except in certain situations.
Somewhat comfortable, but I hold back occasionally.
Often uncomfortable and tend to hide my emotions.
Very uncomfortable and rarely express my emotions.

questions.question: How do you respond to others' emotions in conversations?
options: I empathize and try to understand their feelings deeply.
I acknowledge their emotions and offer support.
I relate to them through similar experiences.
I feel unsure how to respond and often avoid it.
I tend to dismiss or ignore their emotions.

questions.question: How do you manage stress in your relationship?
options: Identify the stressors and proactively address them.
Communicate openly with your partner about what's stressing you.
Engage in relaxing activities together to reduce stress.
Avoid talking about stress to prevent conflicts.
React impulsively to alleviate stress without addressing it.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following emotional awareness types: 1) Proactive Learner, 2) Reflective Analyzer, 3) Intuitive Feeler, 4) Reactive Responder, 5) Detached Observer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Emotional Awareness Type is Proactive Learner, indicating you actively seek to understand and manage your emotions in the relationship.

title: Vulnerability Comfort Type
research: Grounded in Brené Brown's research on vulnerability and its role in emotional connection
description: Discover how comfortable you are with sharing your deeper emotions and personal insecurities with your partner. This test helps you understand your vulnerability style to foster a stronger emotional connection.

questions.question: When you're upset, how do you usually express your feelings to your partner?
options: I openly share my emotions and discuss what's bothering me.
I talk about my feelings but sometimes hold back.
I share my feelings only when I feel completely ready.
I find it hard to express my emotions and often keep them to myself.
I rarely express my feelings and prefer to handle things on my own.

questions.question: How do you feel about sharing your personal fears with your partner?
options: I freely share my fears and find it strengthens our bond.
I share my fears most of the time, with a few exceptions.
I occasionally share my fears when I feel safe.
I find it difficult to share my fears and often keep them hidden.
I avoid sharing my fears altogether as it makes me uncomfortable.

questions.question: In moments of vulnerability, how do you react?
options: I embrace vulnerability and see it as an opportunity for connection.
I am generally open but sometimes guard my true feelings.
I feel neutral and neither seek nor avoid vulnerability.
I tend to avoid vulnerability to protect myself.
I actively resist being vulnerable and prefer to stay detached.

questions.question: When your partner asks about your insecurities, how do you respond?
options: I willingly share my insecurities and discuss them openly.
I share my insecurities but may hold back some details.
I share only minor insecurities and keep the deeper ones hidden.
I struggle to share my insecurities and often change the topic.
I avoid sharing my insecurities and keep them to myself.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with admitting your mistakes to your partner?
options: I am very comfortable and do so without hesitation.
I usually admit my mistakes but sometimes feel uneasy.
I admit my mistakes when I feel it's absolutely necessary.
I find it uncomfortable to admit mistakes and try to avoid it.
I rarely admit my mistakes and often deny them.

questions.question: When facing a tough time, how do you seek support from your partner?
options: I openly reach out and discuss my struggles.
I usually reach out but might hesitate at times.
I reach out only when I feel it's truly necessary.
I rarely reach out and prefer to handle it myself.
I avoid reaching out and keep my struggles to myself.

questions.question: How do you feel about discussing past traumas or significant emotional events with your partner?
options: I feel comfortable and see it as a way to deepen our connection.
I'm generally open but may hesitate with certain topics.
I'm neutral and share only when I feel it's appropriate.
I feel uneasy and prefer not to discuss past traumas.
I strongly avoid discussing past traumas or emotional events.

questions.question: When your partner shares their vulnerabilities, how do you respond?
options: I respond with empathy and support, encouraging more openness.
I listen and offer support, though sometimes I'm unsure how to respond.
I listen but keep my own feelings in check.
I feel uncomfortable and sometimes withdraw.
I avoid engaging and change the subject.

questions.question: How often do you initiate conversations about your deeper emotions with your partner?
options: Very often, as a regular part of our relationship.
Often, but not consistently.
Sometimes, when I feel it's necessary.
Rarely, only in specific situations.
Almost never, I prefer not to initiate such conversations.

questions.question: How do you perceive vulnerability in a relationship?
options: Essential for a strong and meaningful connection.
Important, but it takes time to develop.
Somewhat important, but not always necessary.
Challenging and sometimes risky.
Something to be avoided to maintain stability.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following vulnerability comfort types: 1) Embracer, 2) Generally Open, 3) Occasional Sharer, 4) Avoider, 5) Protector.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Vulnerability Comfort Type is Embracer, indicating you freely share your emotions and see vulnerability as a strength in your relationship.

title: Empathy Resonance Style
research: Based on empathy research and studies on emotional attunement in relationships.
description: Discover how well you connect with your partner's emotions and understand their nonverbal cues. This quiz helps you identify your empathy style to enhance emotional bonding and mutual understanding.

questions.question: When your partner is upset, how do you usually respond?
options: I listen attentively and offer comforting words.
I try to fix the problem immediately.
I give them space to process their feelings.
I mirror their emotions to show understanding.
I distract them with a change of topic.

questions.question: How do you pick up on your partner's mood?
options: I pay attention to their tone of voice and facial expressions.
I ask them directly how they're feeling.
I rely on gut feelings and intuition.
I notice changes in their behavior patterns.
I sometimes miss subtle emotional cues.

questions.question: When discussing emotions, what is your approach?
options: I encourage open and honest sharing of feelings.
I focus on practical solutions to emotional issues.
I share my own experiences to relate to theirs.
I observe and respond based on their nonverbal cues.
I find it challenging to discuss emotions openly.

questions.question: How do you show empathy during disagreements?
options: I validate their feelings and perspectives.
I try to understand the root cause of their emotions.
I remain calm and control my own emotions.
I express similar emotions to connect with them.

Frequently, through both words and actions.

options: I listen without judgment and try to understand their perspective.
I address my discomfort openly and seek clarification.
I empathize by relating it to something I've experienced.

options: I celebrate with them and share in their happiness.
I ask them more about what made them happy.
I express my own happiness in return.
I mirror their enthusiasm to show support.

options: I approach them gently to offer support.
I give them space and check in later.
I interpret their cues and respond accordingly.
I mirror their body language to show empathy.
I sometimes overlook subtle nonverbal cues.

questions.question: When your partner is experiencing a bad day, what is your preferred way to help?
options: I listen to them vent and offer emotional support.
I provide practical assistance to alleviate their stress.
I engage in activities together to lift their spirits.
I express empathy through gestures like a hug or a kind note.
I try to cheer them up with humor or distractions.

questions.question: How do you ensure you understand your partner's emotional needs?
options: I communicate regularly about our feelings and experiences.
I observe their behavior and respond to their cues.
I ask them to share their needs and listen carefully.
I reflect on our interactions to better understand their emotions.
I rely on our established patterns and habits.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Empathy Resonance Styles: 1) Active Listener, 2) Problem Solver, 3) Intuitive Empath, 4) Emotional Mirror, 5) Supportive Companion.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Empathy Resonance Style is Active Listener, indicating you prioritize attentive and validating communication in understanding your partner's emotions.

title: Discover Your Emotional Expression Style
research: Derived from research on emotional expression styles and gender differences in emotional communication.

I give them space and time to process their emotions.
I try to logically understand and address the issue.

I might share it after thinking it through.

options: I address the tension by talking it out.
I take time away to cool down before discussing.

options: I enthusiastically talk and share every detail.
I share my excitement in a subdued way.

title: Feeling Validation Styles
research: Grounded in validation research and Linehan's work on emotional validation in relationships
description: Measures how effectively partners validate each other's emotional experiences without judgment or minimization

questions.question: When your partner shares their feelings, how do you typically respond?
options: I listen carefully and acknowledge their emotions wholeheartedly.
I show understanding and offer supportive words.
I try to help but sometimes get distracted.
I change the topic to lighten the mood.

options: I validate their feelings and discuss solutions together.
I acknowledge their emotions and offer comfort.
I try to fix the issue while listening.

options: I celebrate with them and share in their joy enthusiastically.
I express genuine happiness for their achievements.

options: I empathize deeply and discuss ways to improve the situation.
I acknowledge their feelings and offer support.
I apologize and try to make things better.

options: I spend quality time with them and show affection.

I suggest activities to do together.

I try to cheer them up with humor or a gesture.

title: Emotion Navigation Style
research: Based on research on mixed emotions and managing emotional complexity in relationships.
description: Ever feel like your emotions are a tangled ball of yarn? Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your unique Emotion Navigation Style and learn how you handle those pesky mixed feelings in your relationship!

questions.question: When you're feeling a mix of happiness and frustration, how do you usually react?
options: I talk it out immediately to clear my head.
I take some alone time to sort through my feelings.
I try to focus on the positive and move forward.
I seek advice from a close friend or partner.
I might feel overwhelmed and not know where to start.

options: Acknowledge both emotions and offer support where needed.
Focus on one emotion to avoid confusion.
Encourage them to share all their feelings openly.

options: List the pros and cons to gain clarity.

Discuss it with my partner to get their perspective.

Feel stuck and find it hard to make a choice.

Focus on the excitement and downplay the anxiety.
Seek reassurance from my partner.
Feel conflicted and unsure how to express both emotions.

options: Embrace the complexity and allow myself to feel both.
Prefer to focus on the joyful aspect.
Express my feelings through conversation or journaling.
Look for ways to support my partner through both emotions.
Find it difficult to navigate the mixed feelings.

questions.question: If you're excited about a new opportunity but also nervous, what's your typical response?
options: Share both feelings with someone I trust.
Push aside the nervousness and dive in.
Use the excitement to motivate myself.
Seek advice to manage the nervousness.

options: Listen actively and validate their feelings.
Encourage them to talk it out.
Help them find ways to focus on the positive emotions.
Offer physical comfort and reassurance.

options: Communicate openly about both feelings.
Focus on the love and let irritation pass.
Address the irritation while expressing love.
Seek a compromise to alleviate irritation.

questions.question: When unexpected events trigger mixed emotions, what's your go-to strategy?
options: Assess each emotion individually to understand them better.

title: Emotion Integration Style
research: Derived from narrative therapy research and studies on emotional processing of past experiences
description: This quiz examines how you understand and integrate past emotional experiences into your current relationship dynamic.

questions.question: When reflecting on past disagreements, how do you usually feel?
options: I often think about what I could have done differently.

questions.question: How do you handle memories of past relationships?
options: I use them as lessons to improve my current relationship.
I keep them to myself and rarely think about them.
I share them to build a deeper connection with my partner.

questions.question: When something triggers a past emotional experience, you:
options: Acknowledge it and discuss it to better understand your feelings.

Express it immediately to your partner.

options: I reflect on them to make informed choices.
I avoid thinking about them when making decisions.
I talk about them with my partner to guide our decisions.

Push the issue aside and hope it resolves itself.
Address it openly with your partner right away.

options: Essential for personal and relational growth.
Something to minimize and not think about.

I prefer interactive activities and joint practice sessions.

I value their understanding and empathy.
I want to work through the situation together.

options: I offer practical advice and solutions.

research: Based on active listening techniques and John Gottman's research on relationship communication patterns.

title: Problem Solving Style
research: Based on problem-solving theories and root-cause analysis techniques used in relationship counseling.

questions.question: When planning for the future, your negotiation style is to:
