evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following boundary setting styles: 1) Assertive, 2) Passive, 3) Aggressive, 4) Passive-Aggressive, 5) Unclear.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Boundary Setting Style is Assertive, indicating you communicate your needs clearly and respectfully.

title: Your Trust Building Style
research: Grounded in research on trust-building and its role in relational satisfaction.
description: Discover your unique approach to building and maintaining trust in your relationship. Understanding your Trust Building Style can help you and your partner strengthen your foundation for long-term happiness.

questions.question: When you feel a breach of trust, how do you typically respond?
options: I like to talk openly about my feelings to resolve the issue.
I make sure to follow through on my commitments to regain trust.
I offer support and understanding to help heal the relationship.
I emphasize honesty and transparency to move forward.
I take my time to process my feelings and rebuild trust gradually.

questions.question: How do you prefer to show your partner that they can trust you?
options: Engaging in deep and meaningful conversations regularly.
Being consistently reliable and keeping promises.
Being there for them during tough times without hesitation.
Always being honest, even when it's difficult.
Taking steady and patient steps to demonstrate trustworthiness.

questions.question: When making plans with your partner, what is your approach to ensure trust?
options: Discussing and agreeing on every detail openly.
Making sure to honor the plans and follow through.
Ensuring that the plans support and benefit both of you.
Being transparent about your intentions and actions.
Taking your time to plan thoughtfully and respectfully.

questions.question: How do you handle situations where you need to ask for forgiveness?
options: I openly express my remorse and discuss what went wrong.
I take responsibility and ensure I don't repeat the mistake.
I show my commitment to making things better through actions.
I communicate honestly about my feelings and the situation.
I patiently give space and work on rebuilding trust over time.

questions.question: What makes you feel most secure in trusting your partner?
options: Having open and honest discussions about our feelings.
Knowing that I can depend on them consistently.
Feeling supported and understood in difficult times.
Seeing complete honesty in their words and actions.
Observing their gradual and steady efforts to build trust.

questions.question: How do you prefer to address misunderstandings in your relationship?
options: By having a candid conversation to clear things up.
By taking steps to ensure it doesn't happen again.
By offering support and patience while resolving the issue.
By being completely honest about my perspective.
By calmly working through the issue at a comfortable pace.

questions.question: In terms of personal growth, how do you contribute to a trustworthy relationship?
options: I constantly communicate my thoughts and feelings.
I ensure that I am dependable and truthful in all actions.
I provide unwavering support and understanding.
I maintain complete honesty, even when it's challenging.
I patiently work on building and maintaining trust over time.

questions.question: What do you do when you need to share something sensitive with your partner?
options: I choose a good time to talk and express myself clearly.
I make sure to handle the conversation responsibly.
I provide reassurance and support while sharing.
I speak honestly and transparently about the matter.
I take my time to approach the topic thoughtfully.

questions.question: How do you ensure that your actions align with building trust?
options: By openly discussing my intentions and actions.
By consistently following through on what I say.
By showing up and being there when it matters.
By being truthful and avoiding any deceit.
By steadily and patiently demonstrating reliability.

questions.question: What is your primary focus when trying to rebuild trust after a conflict?
options: Having open discussions to understand each other's perspectives.
Proving reliability through consistent actions.
Providing support and showing that I care.
Maintaining complete honesty to restore trust.
Taking time to patiently work through the issues together.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Trust Building Styles: 1) The Communicator, 2) The Reliable Partner, 3) The Supportive Ally, 4) The Transparent Thinker, 5) The Patient Builder.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Trust Building Style is The Communicator, indicating you prioritize open dialogue and expressing your feelings to build trust in your relationship.

title: Decision-Making Style
research: Inspired by research on collaborative decision-making and shared responsibility in relationships.
description: Discover your unique decision-making style within your relationship. This quiz helps you understand how you approach choices together, fostering a sense of partnership and equality.

questions.question: When faced with a major decision, how do you typically respond?
options: I take the lead and make the decision confidently.
I discuss all options thoroughly with my partner before deciding.
I analyze all possible outcomes carefully before choosing.
I go with my gut feeling and decide quickly.
I tend to avoid making the decision and let my partner choose.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements when deciding on something important?
options: I assert my viewpoint to ensure my perspective is heard.
I seek a compromise that satisfies both of us.
I gather all the facts to support my position.
I suggest taking a break and deciding later.
I prefer to agree to avoid conflict, even if it's not my preference.

questions.question: When planning future goals, what is your approach?
options: I set clear goals and outline steps to achieve them.
I collaborate with my partner to set mutual goals.
I research extensively to make informed plans.
I follow my intuition on what feels right for us.
I leave the planning to my partner and support their decisions.

questions.question: How do you feel about making spontaneous decisions in your relationship?
options: I enjoy making quick decisions and taking initiative.
I like spontaneous decisions as long as we discuss them first.
I prefer spontaneous decisions only after careful consideration.
I'm comfortable with occasional spontaneity without much planning.
I find spontaneous decisions stressful and prefer to plan ahead.

questions.question: When choosing activities to do together, what's your strategy?
options: I decide on activities that I enjoy the most.
I choose activities that we both like through discussion.
I select activities that have been proven to be enjoyable.
I pick activities based on how I'm feeling at the moment.
I leave the choice up to my partner to decide.

questions.question: How do you prioritize tasks when both you and your partner have responsibilities?
options: I prioritize my tasks and help my partner with theirs if needed.
I work together with my partner to prioritize our tasks.
I prioritize tasks based on deadlines and importance.
I handle tasks as they come without strict prioritization.
I rely on my partner to prioritize while I focus on supporting them.

questions.question: In financial decisions, how do you act?
options: I take charge and make financial decisions independently.
I discuss all financial decisions with my partner before acting.
I analyze financial options thoroughly before deciding.
I prefer making financial decisions based on my instincts.
I let my partner handle financial decisions while I support them.

questions.question: When deciding where to live, what is your typical behavior?
options: I make the decision based on my career opportunities.
I collaborate with my partner to choose the best location for both.
I research extensively to find the most suitable place.
I decide based on what feels right in the moment.
I prefer to let my partner choose the location.

questions.question: How do you approach making daily small decisions, like what to eat for dinner?
options: I decide quickly based on my preferences.
I ask for my partner's input before deciding.
I consider all available options before choosing.
I choose based on what I'm craving at the time.
I let my partner decide and go along with it.

questions.question: How do you feel about delegating decisions to your partner?
options: I'm comfortable taking charge and making decisions myself.
I prefer to share decision-making equally with my partner.
I delegate decisions when I feel unsure or need guidance.
I sometimes delegate decisions based on my mood.
I often let my partner take the lead in decision-making.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following decision-making styles: 1) Assertive Leader, 2) Collaborative Partner, 3) Analytical Planner, 4) Intuitive Decider, 5) Supportive Reliever.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Decision-Making Style is Assertive Leader, indicating you take initiative and prefer to lead decisions in your relationship.

title: Intimacy Building Styles
research: Based on attachment theory and research on emotional and physical closeness.
description: Discover your unique ways of building emotional and physical intimacy with your partner. This quiz will help you understand your Intimacy Building Style, fostering a deeper connection and a stronger bond.

questions.question: When you want to feel closer to your partner, what do you usually do?
options: Initiate deep and meaningful conversations.
Seek physical closeness like hugging or holding hands.
Plan and spend quality time together doing activities.
Offer help and support with their daily tasks.
Take time to reflect on your feelings and share them when ready.

questions.question: How do you prefer to express your love and affection?
options: By talking about your feelings and thoughts.
Through physical touch and gestures.
By spending uninterrupted time together.
By assisting them with what they need.
By contemplating and understanding your emotions.

questions.question: When your partner shares something important, how do you respond?
options: Engage in a detailed discussion about it.
Show physical comfort and presence.
Suggest spending time together to support them.
Offer practical help and solutions.
Listen quietly and process your own feelings before responding.

questions.question: What makes you feel most connected to your partner?
options: Having open and honest conversations.
Sharing physical activities and affection.
Participating in fun and engaging activities together.
Seeing them succeed and being there to support them.
Understanding and managing your own emotions within the relationship.

questions.question: How do you like to spend a relaxing evening with your partner?
options: Talking about your day and future plans.
Cuddling on the couch or holding hands.
Going out for a movie or a fun activity.
Helping with household chores or tasks together.
Having some quiet time to reflect individually.

questions.question: In moments of stress, how do you seek intimacy?
options: Discuss your worries and seek understanding.
Find comfort in physical presence and touch.
Engage in activities that distract and entertain.
Rely on your partner to help manage the situation.
Take time alone to process your emotions before connecting.

questions.question: What role do you usually take to nurture your relationship?
options: Facilitating open communication and honesty.
Maintaining physical intimacy and closeness.
Creating enjoyable experiences together.
Providing consistent support and assistance.
Focusing on personal emotional growth and sharing when ready.

questions.question: How do you respond when your partner needs emotional support?
options: Initiate a heartfelt conversation to understand their feelings.
Offer a hug or physical comfort.
Plan a fun activity to lift their spirits.
Help them with tasks to alleviate their burden.
Give them space to process their emotions on their own.

questions.question: What helps you feel secure and intimate in your relationship?
options: Knowing you can openly discuss anything.
Sharing physical affection regularly.
Having fun and enjoying each other's company.
Being able to rely on each other for support.
Having time to reflect on your personal and emotional connection.

questions.question: When thinking about long-term intimacy, what is most important to you?
options: Maintaining deep and ongoing communication.
Continuing to share physical closeness and affection.
Keeping the relationship lively with new experiences.
Ensuring mutual support and reliability.
Focusing on personal growth and emotional understanding within the relationship.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Intimacy Building Styles: 1) The Communicator, 2) The Touch Lover, 3) The Quality Time Seeker, 4) The Supportive Partner, 5) The Reflective Soul.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Intimacy Building Style is The Communicator, indicating you prioritize open and honest conversations to build a deeper connection.

title: Stress Coping Style
research: Drawn from research on stress management and co-regulation in couples.
description: This theme teaches couples how to support each other during stressful times, using techniques to manage external pressures as a team.

questions.question: When a sudden stressor hits, how do you typically respond?
options: Dive straight into finding a solution.
Seek comfort and reassurance from your partner.
Engage in a distracting activity to take your mind off it.
Create a detailed plan to manage the situation.
Handle it quietly on your own without discussing it.

questions.question: How do you prefer to unwind after a particularly stressful day?
options: Tackle any remaining tasks to feel accomplished.
Talk with your partner about how you're feeling.
Watch a movie or play a game to distract yourself.
Organize your schedule for the next day to feel prepared.
Spend some time alone to recharge.

questions.question: When your partner is stressed, what is your go-to support method?
options: Help them brainstorm solutions to their problems.
Offer a listening ear and emotional support.
Suggest doing something fun together to lighten the mood.
Help them plan and organize their tasks to reduce stress.
Give them space to handle it on their own.

questions.question: In moments of high stress, how do you make decisions?
options: Focus on actionable steps to resolve the issue.
Prioritize the emotional well-being of both partners.
Choose to step away and decide later when calmer.
Analyze all possible outcomes carefully before deciding.
Trust your instincts and proceed independently.

questions.question: How do you communicate your needs during stressful times?
options: Clearly articulate what you need to solve the problem.
Express your feelings and seek emotional support.
Communicate indirectly by suggesting activities to distract.
Detail the tasks that need to be done and who will do them.
Keep your needs to yourself to avoid adding more stress.

questions.question: What role do you usually take in managing joint stress with your partner?
options: Taking charge to address and resolve the stressor.
Being the emotional anchor your partner can rely on.
Lightening the mood with humor or fun activities.
Planning and organizing efforts to handle the stress together.
Allowing your partner to lead while you support quietly.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle unexpected changes that cause stress?
options: Quickly find a way to adapt and move forward.
Discuss your feelings about the change with your partner.
Find a new routine that distracts you from the change.
Carefully assess and plan your next steps.
Adjust on your own without involving others.

questions.question: When faced with continuous stress, how do you maintain your well-being?
options: Focus on resolving the underlying issues.
Stay connected with your partner for emotional support.
Engage in hobbies or activities that keep you occupied.
Set structured routines to manage your time effectively.
Take personal time to reflect and decompress.

questions.question: During a prolonged stressful period, how do you keep your relationship strong?
options: Work together to overcome challenges.
Provide constant emotional support to each other.
Find ways to inject fun and relaxation into daily life.
Maintain organization to reduce additional stress.
Respect each other's space and handle stress individually.

questions.question: How do you celebrate small victories after overcoming stress?
options: Acknowledge the solution and plan the next steps.
Share your feelings of relief and happiness with your partner.
Treat yourself to something enjoyable as a reward.
Organize a small celebration to recognize the effort.
Reflect on the success privately.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following stress coping styles: 1) Problem Solver, 2) Emotional Supporter, 3) Distractor, 4) Planner, 5) Independent Adapter.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Stress Coping Style is Problem Solver, indicating you tackle stress by addressing the cause directly and finding solutions.

title: Relationship Growth Style

questions.question: When you encounter a disagreement with your partner, how do you typically respond?

I try to adapt my approach to better handle the situation.

questions.question: How do you approach personal growth within your relationship?
options: I actively seek ways to develop and strengthen our bond.
I am eager to learn from our interactions and improve ourselves.
I remain resilient and committed to growing together.
I adapt to new situations to enhance our relationship.
I find it difficult to pursue growth within the relationship.

questions.question: When faced with a challenge in your relationship, what do you do?
options: I view it as a chance to grow closer and understand each other better.
I am motivated to overcome the challenge and learn through it.
I stay resilient and work through the challenge together.
I adapt my behavior to better handle the challenge.
I often feel stuck and find it hard to manage the challenge.

I am eager to learn and apply new strategies for a better relationship.
I remain resilient and supportive during tough times.
I adapt to new circumstances to foster growth in our relationship.
I struggle to see how I can contribute to growth.

questions.question: How do you feel about trying new things together as a couple?
options: I embrace it as an opportunity for us to grow.
I am excited to learn and experience new activities together.
I stay committed and resilient when trying new things.
I adapt easily to new experiences to enhance our relationship.
I feel hesitant or resistant to trying new things.

questions.question: When planning for the future, how do you consider potential challenges?
options: I see them as opportunities to strengthen our relationship.
I am motivated to develop strategies to overcome them.
I stay resilient and confident we can handle future challenges.
I adapt our plans as needed to address potential issues.
I worry about how challenges might affect our relationship.

questions.question: How do you approach disagreements about major life decisions?
options: I look for ways to grow and understand each other's perspectives.
I am motivated to find a solution that benefits our relationship.
I stay resilient and work together to make the best decision.
I adapt my viewpoint to accommodate the discussion.
I find it difficult to navigate disagreements on major decisions.

questions.question: How important is personal development within your relationship?
options: Very important; I actively pursue personal growth for our relationship.
Important; I seek opportunities to learn and improve together.
Important; I stay resilient and support personal growth in our relationship.
Somewhat important; I adapt as needed for personal development.
Not very important; I find it challenging to focus on personal growth within the relationship.

questions.question: How do you react when your relationship faces unexpected changes?
options: I view changes as opportunities for growth and improvement.
I am motivated to learn from the changes and adapt accordingly.
I stay resilient and work through the changes together.
I adapt easily to the changes to benefit our relationship.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following relationship growth styles: 1) Growth Champion, 2) Learning Enthusiast, 3) Resilient Partner, 4) Adaptable Thinker, 5) Stagnant Mindset.

title: Emotional Safety Style
research: Based on attachment theory (Bowlby & Ainsworth) and research on emotional security in relationships
description: Discover how emotionally safe you feel in your relationship. This index evaluates your comfort with vulnerability and your emotional responsiveness to your partner.

questions.question: How comfortable are you sharing your deepest fears with your partner?
options: Very comfortable, I feel they understand me well.

options: They listen attentively and supportively.
They try to reassure me with kind words.
They give me space to deal with it on my own.
Their response is unpredictable and sometimes distant.
They often ignore my feelings or change the subject.

questions.question: How do you handle conflicts in your relationship?
options: We discuss openly and find solutions together.
I seek reassurance after a conflict.
I tend to withdraw and avoid confrontation.
I feel anxious and worry it will lead to a breakup.

questions.question: Do you feel safe being vulnerable with your partner?
options: Yes, I feel completely safe to be myself.

I want to be vulnerable but fear it might backfire.

options: Rarely, I'm confident in our relationship.
Occasionally, when I have doubts.

I seek reassurance but feel uneasy about doing so.

options: Express them openly and honestly.
Share them when necessary.
Keep them to myself most of the time.

options: They understand and prioritize my needs.
They generally recognize my needs.
They rarely acknowledge my emotional needs.
I'm unsure how they view my needs.

questions.question: Do you trust your partner with your secrets or sensitive information?
options: Yes, I trust them completely.
Yes, but with some reservations.
I'm hesitant but mostly trust them.

options: Yes, they are very supportive.
Sometimes, depending on the situation.
Not often, I handle stress on my own.

No, I feel unsupported when stressed.

questions.question: How do you perceive the overall emotional climate of your relationship?
options: Stable and supportive.
Generally positive with occasional bumps.

title: Reliability Patterns Type

options: Always, without fail.

options: Inform them immediately and find an alternative solution.
Let them know as soon as I realize.

questions.question: How consistent are you in keeping small promises, like running an errand or making a phone call?
options: I never miss small promises.
I almost always keep them.
I keep them most of the time.
I sometimes forget or get distracted.
I often fail to keep them.

questions.question: When planning something important with your partner, how reliable are you in sticking to the agreed plan?
options: I adhere strictly to the plan without changes.
I follow the plan with minor adjustments when necessary.
I sometimes deviate from the plan based on circumstances.
I frequently change the plan as needed.
I rarely stick to the plan and often go off track.

options: I will always attend without any excuse.
I usually attend unless something unavoidable happens.
I attend most of the time.
I might miss it due to other commitments.
I often fail to show up.

options: I prioritize commitments and plan my schedule accordingly.
I make an effort to manage my time effectively.
I try to manage my time but sometimes struggle.
I find it challenging to manage my time for commitments.
I rarely manage my time to meet commitments.

questions.question: When your partner relies on you for support, how dependable are you in providing it?

I am usually dependable when they need support.

I feel disappointed but try to move on.

Sometimes set realistic expectations.
Rarely set realistic expectations.

questions.question: When faced with unexpected changes, how reliably do you adjust your commitments to accommodate your partner?
options: I adjust immediately and reliably.
I adjust with minimal delay.
I adjust but it might take some time.
I find it difficult to adjust reliably.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following reliability patterns: 1) Highly Reliable, 2) Consistently Dependable, 3) Moderately Reliable, 4) Occasionally Unreliable, 5) Unreliable.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Reliability Patterns Type is Highly Reliable, indicating you consistently follow through on your commitments and are a pillar of dependability in your relationship.

title: Transparency Style
research: Based on self-disclosure research and studies on openness in relationship development
description: Measures the level of openness and honesty between partners, including comfort with sharing sensitive information and maintaining appropriate boundaries.

questions.question: When something bothers you, how do you usually communicate it to your partner?
options: I openly discuss it immediately without hesitation.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with sharing your past experiences with your partner?
options: I freely share detailed stories and insights from my past.
I share significant events that have shaped who I am.
I discuss my past when it's relevant to the current situation.

questions.question: When facing a personal challenge, how do you seek support from your partner?
options: I immediately open up and seek their help and advice.
I share my struggles once I feel comfortable and trust them.

I hint at my struggles but prefer to handle most of it on my own.
I avoid discussing my challenges to maintain my independence.

questions.question: How do you handle sharing sensitive information, such as financial issues or family matters?

I discuss important matters thoroughly when needed.
I provide enough information to keep my partner informed.
I share only what's necessary to address the issue.
I prefer to keep sensitive information private and handle it myself.

questions.question: How often do you reveal your feelings and emotions to your partner?
options: I express my emotions freely and regularly.
I share my feelings openly most of the time.
I discuss my emotions when I feel it's important.
I express my feelings sparingly and mostly when asked.
I rarely share my emotions and keep them internal.

questions.question: When making decisions that affect both of you, how transparent are you about your thoughts?
options: I openly share all my thoughts and include my partner in every step.
I discuss my plans and seek input before deciding.
I share my main ideas and consider my partner's opinions.
I provide essential information and prefer to make decisions independently.
I keep my thoughts private and make decisions on my own.

I share my goals when relevant to our relationship.

I share my thoughts while trying to find common ground.

questions.question: How do you handle sharing feedback, both positive and negative, with your partner?

title: Trust Repair Style Type
research: Derived from Gottman's research on relationship repair attempts and trust rebuilding after conflicts.
description: Discover your unique style of responding to trust breaches and learn how effectively you rebuild trust with your partner. This test helps you understand your approach to reconciliation and fosters a deeper connection through better trust management.

questions.question: When a disagreement arises between you and your partner, what's your first instinct?
options: I immediately apologize and seek to make amends.
I focus on finding a practical solution to prevent it from happening again.
I express my feelings about the situation to process my emotions.
I tend to avoid the issue and hope it resolves on its own.
I suggest we work together to understand and fix the problem.

questions.question: If you've broken your partner's trust, how do you typically address it?
options: Offer a sincere apology and ask for forgiveness.
Provide practical steps to regain trust.
Discuss the emotions involved openly.
Downplay the issue and hope it gets better.
Collaborate on rebuilding trust together.

questions.question: When remembering past conflicts, how do you usually react?
options: Feel remorseful and seek to make things right.
Analyze what went wrong and how to prevent it.
Reflect on your feelings during the conflict.
Try to forget and move on without much discussion.
Talk with your partner to understand and heal together.

questions.question: How do you handle it when your partner expresses hurt over something you did?
options: Apologize immediately and seek to mend things.
Offer solutions to fix the mistake.
Share your feelings about why it happened.
Minimize their feelings or the event.
Engage in a joint effort to resolve the hurt.

questions.question: When trying to resolve a trust issue, what's your approach?
options: Take responsibility and seek to apologize.
Focus on actionable steps to rectify the issue.
Express and explore your emotional responses.
Avoid confrontation and distance yourself.
Work together with your partner to find a solution.

questions.question: After a mistake in the relationship, what do you usually do?
options: Quickly say sorry and make up.
Plan how to fix the mistake and prevent it next time.
Talk about how the mistake made you feel.
Avoid talking about it and hope it resolves.
Discuss together how to move forward as a team.

questions.question: When facing a breach of trust, how do you communicate with your partner?
options: Express your regret and ask for forgiveness.
Suggest concrete ways to rebuild trust.
Share your emotional perspective on the breach.
Keep communication minimal to avoid conflict.
Collaborate on rebuilding trust by discussing it together.

questions.question: How do you respond when your partner is upset about something you did?
options: Apologize and take responsibility for your actions.
Offer practical solutions to make things right.
Open up about your feelings and listen to theirs.
Distance yourself to avoid further conflict.
Work with your partner to address and resolve the issue.

questions.question: What is your typical response after realizing you've let your partner down?
options: Immediately apologize and seek to make amends.
Identify steps to correct the mistake and prevent recurrence.
Discuss the emotions both you and your partner are feeling.
Avoid discussing it and hope the issue fades.
Engage in a joint discussion to rebuild trust together.

questions.question: After a conflict, how do you prefer to reconnect with your partner?
options: Apologize and express wanting to make things right.
Talk about what can be done to improve the situation.
Share your feelings and listen to theirs about the conflict.
Give space and avoid further discussion.
Collaborate on strategies to strengthen trust moving forward.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following trust repair styles: 1) Apologizer, 2) Problem-solver, 3) Emotion-focused, 4) Deflector, 5) Collaborative Reconciler.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Trust Repair Style is Apologizer, indicating you readily acknowledge mistakes and seek to make amends quickly.

title: Boundary Respect Style
research: Based on psychological boundary theory and research on trust development in intimate relationships, this scale evaluates how individuals understand, communicate, and respect their own and their partner's personal boundaries.
description: Understanding and respecting each other's boundaries is crucial for building trust in a relationship. This fun and insightful quiz will help you discover your Boundary Respect Style and learn how you can better support each other's personal limits.

questions.question: When your partner needs some alone time, how do you usually respond?
options: I give them space without taking it personally.
I feel a bit uneasy but respect their need.
I ask if everything is okay and offer support.
I sometimes struggle to understand why they need space.
I might feel rejected and seek immediate reassurance.

questions.question: How do you communicate your personal needs to your partner?
options: I clearly express what I need in a respectful manner.
I wait for the right moment to bring it up.
I try to hint at my needs indirectly.
I find it difficult to express my needs openly.
I often keep my needs to myself to avoid conflict.

questions.question: When setting boundaries, what is your approach?
options: I establish clear and specific boundaries from the start.
I set boundaries gradually as needed.
I discuss boundaries openly with my partner.
I sometimes overlook setting boundaries to keep peace.
I find it challenging to set and maintain boundaries.

questions.question: How do you handle it when your partner's boundaries differ from yours?
options: I respect their boundaries and find a compromise.
I try to understand their perspective and adapt.
I discuss our differences to reach mutual understanding.
I occasionally feel frustrated but manage to respect them.
I struggle to accept their boundaries and feel conflicted.

questions.question: What do you do if your boundaries are crossed?
options: I address it calmly and reiterate my boundaries.
I take time to cool off before discussing it.
I talk to my partner about how it made me feel.
I might avoid bringing it up to prevent arguments.
I feel hurt and find it hard to move past it.

questions.question: How important is it for you to have personal time apart from your partner?
options: Very important; it helps me recharge and stay balanced.
Somewhat important; I enjoy time alone occasionally.
Moderately important; I like a mix of togetherness and alone time.
Slightly important; I prefer spending most of my time together.
Not important; I like being together all the time.

questions.question: When discussing sensitive topics, how do you ensure boundaries are respected?
options: I establish ground rules beforehand and stick to them.
I approach the conversation with empathy and patience.
I make sure both of us feel safe to express our feelings.
I try to keep the conversation light to avoid discomfort.
I avoid sensitive topics to prevent boundary issues.

questions.question: How do you feel when your partner respects your boundaries?
options: Valued and understood, strengthening our trust.
Appreciated and secure in the relationship.
Comfortable and more connected.
Grateful but still wanting more interaction.
Satisfied but occasionally unsure if boundaries are clear.

questions.question: How do you prioritize your boundaries in everyday interactions?
options: I consistently maintain my boundaries in all situations.
I mostly keep my boundaries but sometimes relax them.
I adapt my boundaries based on the context.
I sometimes forget to uphold my boundaries.
I rarely maintain my boundaries, letting others lead.

questions.question: What role do boundaries play in your overall trust within the relationship?
options: They are fundamental and essential for trust.
They significantly contribute to building trust.
They help in maintaining trust and respect.
They have a moderate impact on trust.
They have little to no effect on trust.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Boundary Respect Styles: 1) The Respectful Communicator, 2) The Balancer, 3) The Empathetic Listener, 4) The Peacekeeper, 5) The Struggler.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Boundary Respect Style is The Respectful Communicator, indicating you excel at clearly expressing and upholding personal boundaries while respecting your partner's limits.

title: Digital Trust Style
research: Grounded in modern relationship research on technology use and trust in the digital age
description: Assesses trust dynamics in digital communication and social media use, including privacy expectations and online behavior agreements.

questions.question: How do you handle sharing your relationship status on social media?
options: I love posting about it to celebrate our relationship!
I prefer to keep it private and share only with close friends.
I share it occasionally, depending on the situation.
I'm neutral; sometimes I post, sometimes I don't.
I rarely or never share my relationship status online.

questions.question: When your partner wants to share photos online, how do you feel?
options: Excited and fully support sharing our moments.
Concerned about privacy and prefer limiting posts.
Agree most of the time, but have some reservations.
Indifferent; it doesn't affect me much.
Uncomfortable and prefer not to share at all.

questions.question: How do you react if your partner likes certain posts or photos?
options: Happy for them and see it as a form of support.
Worried it might lead to misunderstandings.
It depends on the context of the likes.
Neutral; doesn't bother me either way.
Upset and feel it's a breach of trust.

questions.question: How do you approach discussing online friendships your partner has?
options: I openly talk about them and encourage transparency.
I express my concerns and discuss boundaries.
I ask questions to understand their relationships better.
I rarely bring it up unless something seems off.
I feel uneasy and keep my feelings to myself.

questions.question: When using shared devices, how do you view privacy?
options: I'm open and have no issues sharing passwords.
I believe in setting some boundaries for privacy.
I share some information but keep certain things private.
I'm somewhat cautious but not overly restrictive.
I maintain strict privacy and don't share sensitive information.

questions.question: How do you feel about your partner checking your social media activity?
options: Comfortable and see it as a way to stay connected.
A bit uneasy but understand their intentions.
It depends on what they are looking for.
Uncomfortable but don't say anything about it.
Upset and view it as an invasion of privacy.

questions.question: How do you ensure your online interactions build trust in your relationship?
options: Regularly communicate and share openly online.
Set clear boundaries and respect each other's privacy.
Balance openness with personal privacy as needed.
Maintain a neutral stance and let trust develop naturally.
Prefer to keep online and offline lives completely separate.

questions.question: How do you manage disagreements about online behavior?
options: Discuss openly and find a compromise together.
Express my feelings and work towards understanding.
Seek to understand their perspective before responding.
Avoid confrontation and hope it resolves itself.
Feel frustrated and withdraw from the discussion.

questions.question: How important is it for you to have mutual agreements on social media use?
options: Very important; we have clear agreements in place.
Somewhat important; we discuss major points.
Moderately important; we have informal understandings.
Not very important; we handle it as it comes.
Not important at all; everyone manages their own use.

questions.question: How do you feel when your partner shares your photos without asking?
options: Happy and see it as a sign of pride in our relationship.
A little surprised but not too concerned.
Feel it's okay as long as it's positive.
Prefer to be asked first but it's not a big deal.
Upset and wish they had asked before sharing.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following digital trust styles: 1) Open Communicator, 2) Privacy Protector, 3) Collaborative Sharer, 4) Cautious Observer, 5) Distrustful User.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Digital Trust Style is Open Communicator, indicating you are transparent and open in your digital interactions.

title: Support Verification Style
research: Based on perceived partner support research and its role in trust development
description: Measures how partners demonstrate and perceive mutual support, examining the connection between reliable support and trust building

questions.question: When your partner is stressed, how do you typically offer support?
options: I listen attentively and let them vent their feelings.
I help them with practical tasks to alleviate their stress.
I give them encouraging words to boost their morale.
I find creative ways to cheer them up and distract them.
I respect their space and give them time alone.

questions.question: How do you prefer to show appreciation to your partner?
options: By expressing my feelings openly and honestly.
By taking care of something they need help with.
By giving them verbal compliments and encouragement.
By planning fun activities or surprises for them.
By quietly supporting them without much fuss.

questions.question: When your partner achieves something, how do you react?
options: I celebrate their success and share in their joy.
I help them organize their next steps or tasks.
I offer praise and express how proud I am of them.
I create a special celebration or unique way to acknowledge their achievement.
I acknowledge quietly and let them enjoy it on their own.

questions.question: How do you handle disagreements with your partner?
options: I address their feelings and try to understand their perspective.
I work on solutions to resolve the issue practically.
I reassure them that our relationship is strong and that we can overcome it.
I seek creative compromises that satisfy both of us.
I prefer to take time to cool off before discussing.

questions.question: What do you do when your partner is feeling down?
options: I provide a shoulder to cry on and talk through their emotions.
I assist them with any tasks or responsibilities they're struggling with.
I encourage them with positive affirmations and motivational talk.
I distract them with fun activities or humor.
I give them space and wait for them to reach out to me.

questions.question: How do you like to spend supportive time with your partner?
options: Having deep conversations about our feelings and experiences.
Working together on projects or household tasks.
Sharing compliments and positive feedback about each other.
Engaging in creative or spontaneous activities together.
Enjoying quiet time side by side without much interaction.

questions.question: When your partner faces a challenge, what's your first instinct to help?
options: Offering a listening ear to let them express themselves.
Providing practical assistance to solve the problem.
Boosting their confidence with supportive words.
Coming up with innovative ideas to tackle the challenge.
Observing their needs and offering help only if they ask.

questions.question: How do you prefer to celebrate your partner's special occasions?
options: Sharing heartfelt sentiments and emotional expressions.
Organizing and handling the logistics to make the day smooth.
Complimenting them and expressing genuine admiration.
Planning unique and fun activities to make the day memorable.
Keeping it low-key and letting them enjoy it as they wish.

questions.question: How do you respond when your partner needs to talk after a long day?
options: I make sure to give them my full attention and empathy.
I offer to help with any tasks to ease their burden.
I reassure them and reinforce my support for them.
I lighten the mood with jokes or fun distractions.
I listen quietly without imposing my own opinions.

questions.question: What's your approach to maintaining trust in your relationship?
options: Being emotionally available and understanding.
Being reliable and consistently helping with responsibilities.
Offering constant reassurance and positive affirmations.
Keeping the relationship exciting with new and creative interactions.
Respecting personal boundaries and allowing individual space.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following support styles: 1) Emotional Supporter, 2) Practical Supporter, 3) Affirmative Supporter, 4) Creative Supporter, 5) Reserved Supporter.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Support Style is Emotional Supporter, indicating you prioritize emotional connection and being there for your partner's feelings.

title: Trust Recovery Style
research: Based on trauma-informed relationship research and studies on trust recovery, this quiz explores how past relationship experiences shape your current trust dynamics and offers strategies to overcome trust-related challenges.
description: Ever wondered how your past experiences influence how you trust your partner today? Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Trust Recovery Style and learn ways to build a stronger, more trusting relationship!

questions.question: When you've been hurt in the past, how do you typically approach rebuilding trust in a new relationship?
options: I take my time and set clear boundaries to protect myself.
I prefer to talk openly with my partner about my feelings and concerns.
I focus on my own healing and work on trusting myself first.
I work together with my partner to address issues and rebuild trust.
I often find it hard to trust again and may pull away emotionally.

questions.question: How do you handle reminders of past trust issues when they arise in your current relationship?
options: I remind myself of the present and what's different now.
I discuss them openly with my partner to prevent misunderstandings.
I seek support from friends or a therapist to process my feelings.
I collaborate with my partner to find solutions and move forward.
I feel overwhelmed and struggle to move past them.

questions.question: If a situation threatens your trust in your partner, what's your initial reaction?
options: I become cautious and assess the situation carefully.
I immediately communicate my feelings and concerns with my partner.
I retreat inward and try to handle my emotions on my own.
I engage my partner in finding a mutual resolution.
I feel anxious and may find it hard to address the issue.

questions.question: How do you prefer to receive reassurance from your partner when dealing with trust issues?
options: I appreciate it when they respect my space and boundaries.
I like verbal reassurances and open discussions about trust.
I find comfort in personal reflection and self-care activities.
I value joint efforts to resolve trust issues together.
I may need extra emotional support and understanding.

questions.question: When reflecting on past relationships, what affects your current trust the most?
options: Past breaches of trust make me cautious.
The lack of open communication impacted my trust.
My ability to heal independently influences my trust.
How we work together as a couple affects our trust.
Residual emotional pain makes it hard to fully trust again.

questions.question: In moments of doubt about your partner's trustworthiness, how do you respond?
options: I take time to gather facts before jumping to conclusions.
I address my doubts openly with my partner to seek clarity.
I focus on my personal growth to feel more secure.
I involve my partner in addressing my concerns collaboratively.
I may struggle to overcome the doubts and feel insecure.

questions.question: How do you ensure that past trust issues do not negatively impact your current relationship?
options: By maintaining clear boundaries and being cautious.
By fostering open and honest communication with my partner.
By focusing on my own well-being and resilience.
By working together with my partner to build trust continuously.
I find it challenging to prevent past issues from affecting the present.

questions.question: What strategies do you use to rebuild trust after a disagreement or mistake?
options: I take time to reflect and decide how to proceed.
I discuss the issue thoroughly to understand each other's perspectives.
I engage in activities that help me regain my confidence.
I collaborate with my partner to find constructive solutions.
I feel hurt and may find it hard to move forward.

questions.question: How important is transparency to you when building trust with your partner?
options: Very important; I need to see consistent actions over time.
Crucial; open communication is key for me.
Important, but I balance it with personal privacy.
Essential; working together openly strengthens our trust.
I find it difficult to maintain transparency due to past hurts.

questions.question: In what way do you prefer to celebrate progress in rebuilding trust with your partner?
options: Acknowledging small victories and staying positive.
Having open conversations about our growth.
Treating myself to something special as a reward.
Celebrating together through shared activities.
I may find it hard to recognize progress and feel discouraged.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Trust Recovery Styles: 1) Cautious Rebuilder, 2) Open Communicator, 3) Self-Reliant Healer, 4) Collaborative Restorer, 5) Emotionally Vulnerable.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Trust Recovery Style is Cautious Rebuilder, indicating you approach rebuilding trust with care and clear boundaries.

title: Financial Trust Style
research: Based on research on financial transparency and trust in romantic relationships
description: Evaluates trust in financial matters, including transparency about money, shared financial decision-making, and financial fidelity.

questions.question: How do you approach discussing finances with your partner?
options: I openly share all my financial details regularly.
I share important financial information when necessary.
I prefer not to discuss finances unless it's about big decisions.
I avoid financial discussions to prevent conflicts.
I only share financial information when asked.

questions.question: When it comes to budgeting, how do you handle it?
options: I create detailed budgets and track every expense.
I have a general budget and occasionally review it.
I follow a flexible budget without strict tracking.
I rely on my partner to handle the budgeting.
I don't use a budget and spend as I go.

questions.question: How do you feel about your partner making big financial decisions?
options: I feel comfortable and trust their judgment completely.
I prefer to discuss and make decisions together.
I support their decisions but like to have input.
I feel uneasy and prefer to handle financial decisions myself.
I disapprove of them making financial decisions without consulting me.

questions.question: What do you do if you find a discrepancy in your financial accounts?
options: I address it immediately and discuss it openly.
I review it thoroughly before bringing it up.
I mention it to my partner and we figure it out together.
I might ignore it to avoid confrontation.
I confront my partner about potential dishonesty.

questions.question: How much do you rely on your partner for financial support?
options: I fully depend on them for my financial needs.
I rely on them for major financial aspects.
I am partly dependent and partly independent financially.
I mostly support myself but occasionally need help.
I am completely financially independent.

questions.question: How do you feel about having joint bank accounts?
options: I think it's essential for transparency and trust.
I prefer having a mix of joint and separate accounts.
I'm open to it, but it's not a priority.
I prefer having separate accounts for privacy.
I strongly prefer not to have any joint accounts.

questions.question: When unexpected expenses arise, how do you handle them?
options: We handle them together transparently.
I discuss with my partner before taking action.
I take care of them on my own unless it's major.
I rely on my partner to manage them.
I feel stressed and unsure how to proceed.

questions.question: How do you prioritize financial goals in your relationship?
options: We set and pursue financial goals together.
I have my own financial goals and share them with my partner.
We have separate financial goals that complement each other.
I focus on my partner's financial goals.
We rarely discuss financial goals.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with your partner having their own financial interests?
options: Very comfortable; I support their financial independence.
I'm comfortable as long as it doesn't affect us negatively.
Somewhat comfortable; I have minor reservations.
Not very comfortable; it makes me uneasy.
Uncomfortable; I prefer they don't have separate financial interests.

questions.question: How do you view financial fidelity in a relationship?
options: It's crucial; complete honesty is essential.
It's important but minor lapses can be forgiven.
It's somewhat important; I might overlook small issues.
It's not as important as other aspects of trust.
I don't think financial fidelity is necessary.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following financial trust styles: 1) Transparent Planner, 2) Collaborative Partner, 3) Independent Manager, 4) Guarded Guardian, 5) Secretive Spender.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Financial Trust Style is Transparent Planner, indicating you prioritize open financial communication and detailed planning with your partner.

title: Quality Time Style
research: Based on Gottman's research on relationship rituals and the importance of shared meaningful experiences
description: Measures the quality and quantity of intentional time you spend with your partner, evaluating both daily interactions and dedicated relationship-building activities.

questions.question: When planning a date night, what do you prefer to do?
options: Create a detailed plan with specific activities.
Go with the flow and decide on the spot.
Engage in meaningful conversations over dinner.
Participate in a fun activity or hobby together.
Simply relax and enjoy each other's company without any plans.

questions.question: How do you feel about setting aside time each week for just you and your partner?
options: I like to schedule regular date nights in advance.
I prefer spontaneous dates based on the mood.
I enjoy times when we can talk deeply and connect emotionally.
I love doing something active together during our time.
I value peaceful, unstructured time together.

questions.question: What do you consider most important during the time you spend with your partner?
options: Organized activities that we both enjoy.
The ability to adapt and try new things on the spot.
Having meaningful and heartfelt conversations.
Engaging in shared hobbies or interests.
Relaxing together without any specific agenda.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle downtime in your relationship?
options: Plan a specific activity to do together.
Decide spontaneously what to do based on the day.
Use the time to talk and connect.
Get involved in a mutual hobby or project.
Simply be with each other without doing anything in particular.

questions.question: When you have free time, what do you most look forward to sharing with your partner?
options: Attending a planned event or outing.
Going on an unexpected adventure.
Spending time discussing our thoughts and feelings.
Playing a game or doing a shared activity.
Enjoying a quiet evening together.

questions.question: How do you like to celebrate weekends with your partner?
options: Having a scheduled activity or event.
Being spontaneous and deciding activities as you go.
Having long, meaningful conversations throughout the day.
Participating in outdoor or physical activities together.
Relaxing at home and unwinding together.

questions.question: What makes your quality time with your partner most fulfilling?
options: Having a planned structure to our time together.
Experiencing unexpected and fun moments.
Sharing deep and personal conversations.
Engaging in shared interests or hobbies.
Enjoying each other's presence in a relaxed setting.

questions.question: How do you approach making the most of your time with your partner?
options: I like to plan our activities carefully.
I enjoy spontaneous plans and surprises.
I focus on connecting through conversations.
I prefer doing activities that we both enjoy.
I value simply being together without specific plans.

questions.question: What type of activities do you feel enhance your time together the most?
options: Structured events like concerts or workshops.
Impromptu outings or trying new things spontaneously.
Conversations where we share our thoughts and feelings.
Shared physical activities like hiking or sports.
Relaxing together in a comfortable environment.

questions.question: When reflecting on your time spent with your partner, what stands out the most?
options: The organized events and plans we've made together.
The spontaneous adventures and surprises we've had.
The deep conversations and emotional connections we've shared.
The fun activities and hobbies we've pursued together.
The peaceful and relaxed moments of being together.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Quality Time Styles: 1) Structured Planner, 2) Spontaneous Improviser, 3) Conversational Connector, 4) Activity-Oriented Partner, 5) Relaxed Companion.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Quality Time Style is Structured Planner, indicating you prefer organized and planned activities with your partner.

title: Emotional Reciprocity Style
research: Grounded in emotional exchange theory and research on emotional responsiveness in relationships, this quiz assesses the balance of emotional give-and-take between partners, including emotional awareness, validation, and mutual support patterns.
description: Ever wondered how balanced your emotional exchanges are with your partner? Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Emotional Reciprocity Style and learn how you can enhance the emotional harmony in your relationship!

questions.question: When your partner shares good news, how do you typically respond?
options: Celebrate enthusiastically and share in their joy.
Express happiness and ask more about it.
Feel happy but find it hard to show excitement.
Acknowledge it briefly and move on to another topic.
Feel overwhelmed and unsure how to respond.

questions.question: How do you handle it when your partner is feeling down?
options: Offer comfort and spend quality time together to lift their spirits.
Listen attentively and validate their feelings.
Provide practical solutions to help them feel better.
Give them space and let them process their emotions alone.
Feel stressed and unsure of how to help.

questions.question: When you're upset, how do you prefer your partner to respond?
options: Listen and empathize without trying to fix the problem.
Offer comforting words and physical affection.
Help by taking care of tasks to reduce your stress.
Encourage you to talk about your feelings in detail.
Give you space until you're ready to talk.

questions.question: How often do you share your daily feelings with your partner?
options: Regularly and openly, both good and bad.
Mostly the positive feelings, sharing negatives when necessary.
Occasionally, depending on the situation.
Rarely, I tend to keep my feelings to myself.
Almost never, I prefer not to discuss my feelings.

questions.question: How do you show appreciation to your partner?
options: Express gratitude frequently and specifically.
Perform thoughtful gestures and acts of kindness.
Spend quality time together to show you care.
Give compliments and verbal affirmations.
I find it hard to express appreciation regularly.

questions.question: When your partner needs emotional support, what do you typically do?
options: Immediately offer a shoulder to lean on and be present.
Ask them how you can best support them.
Provide practical help to alleviate their stress.
Listen quietly and let them lead the conversation.
Feel unsure and worry about saying the wrong thing.

questions.question: How do you react when your partner shares their worries?
options: Provide reassurance and help them see the positive side.
Listen attentively and validate their feelings.
Offer solutions to help them overcome their worries.
Encourage them to talk more about what's bothering them.
Feel uncomfortable and try to change the subject.

questions.question: In moments of joy, how do you usually involve your partner?
options: Share every detail and celebrate together enthusiastically.
Invite them to join in the fun and make plans together.
Express your happiness and include them in celebrations.
Mention your joy and hope they feel happy for you.
Keep your joy to yourself and enjoy it independently.

questions.question: How do you ensure emotional needs are met in your relationship?
options: Regularly check in with each other about feelings and needs.
Communicate openly about what makes us feel supported.
Make an effort to understand and respond to each other's emotions.
Show care through actions and small gestures.
I rely on my partner to take the lead in addressing emotional needs.

questions.question: When facing a disagreement, how do you maintain emotional balance?
options: Stay calm and focus on understanding each other's perspectives.
Express your feelings clearly and listen to your partner's side.
Seek common ground and work towards a mutually satisfying solution.
Take breaks if needed to prevent emotions from escalating.
Feel overwhelmed and struggle to maintain composure.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Emotional Reciprocity Styles: 1) Balanced Giver and Taker, 2) Emotionally Supportive, 3) Practical Helper, 4) Reserved Responder, 5) Emotionally Overwhelmed.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Emotional Reciprocity Style is Balanced Giver and Taker, indicating a healthy balance of giving and receiving emotional support in your relationship.

title: Intimacy Development Style
research: Based on Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love and research on intimate connection in relationships
description: Measures multiple dimensions of intimacy (emotional, physical, intellectual) and identifies areas for deepening connection

questions.question: When you think about what makes your relationship strong, what comes to mind first?
options: Sharing and discussing feelings openly.
Enjoying physical closeness and affection.
Engaging in stimulating conversations and intellectual activities.
Being there to support your partner in times of need.
Balancing emotional, physical, and intellectual connections.

questions.question: How do you prefer to spend quality time with your partner?
options: Talking about your day and expressing your feelings.
Cuddling while watching a movie or being physically close.
Learning something new together or discussing interesting topics.
Helping each other with tasks and being supportive.
A mix of activities that include talking, physical affection, and shared interests.

questions.question: What makes you feel most connected to your partner?
options: Having deep and meaningful emotional conversations.
Sharing hugs, kisses, and other forms of physical touch.
Collaborating on projects or engaging in intellectual debates.
Providing and receiving support during stressful times.
Experiencing a well-rounded connection that includes emotion, touch, and intellect.

questions.question: When resolving conflicts, what approach do you take?
options: Expressing your feelings and discussing emotional impacts.
Using physical gestures like holding hands to soothe tensions.
Analyzing the situation logically and finding rational solutions.
Offering support and understanding to your partner's perspective.
Integrating emotional discussion, physical comfort, and thoughtful problem-solving.

questions.question: How do you express love most naturally?
options: Sharing your innermost feelings and emotions.
Showing affection through hugs, kisses, and touch.
Engaging in thoughtful conversations and intellectual pursuits together.
Being there to help and support your partner when needed.
Combining emotional sharing, physical affection, and intellectual engagement.

questions.question: What type of gesture from your partner makes you feel closest to them?
options: A heartfelt conversation or emotional disclosure.
A spontaneous hug or a tender touch.
Discussing a new idea or exploring a shared interest.
Assisting you with a task or being supportive during a tough time.
A balanced gesture that includes emotional, physical, and intellectual elements.

questions.question: How do you like to celebrate your relationship milestones?
options: Reflecting on shared emotions and expressing your love.
Enjoying physical activities like dancing or a romantic dinner.
Participating in intellectually stimulating activities or learning something new together.
Supporting each other in planning and organizing the celebration.
Celebrating with a combination of emotional expressions, physical activities, and shared learning experiences.

questions.question: When planning a future together, what aspect is most important to you?
options: Ensuring emotional compatibility and connection.
Maintaining physical intimacy and closeness.
Having intellectual growth and shared goals.
Providing mutual support and understanding.
Balancing emotional, physical, and intellectual plans for the future.

questions.question: How do you recharge after a long day in your relationship?
options: Talking about your feelings and experiences.
Enjoying physical relaxation and cuddling.
Engaging in a hobby or intellectual activity together.
Supporting each other and sharing responsibilities.
Combining activities that involve emotional sharing, physical relaxation, and intellectual engagement.

questions.question: What is your primary way of maintaining a strong bond with your partner?
options: Regularly discussing your emotions and feelings.
Keeping physical affection consistent and meaningful.
Engaging in continuous learning and intellectual discussions.
Being consistently supportive and dependable.
Maintaining a harmonious balance of emotional, physical, and intellectual interactions.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following intimacy development styles: 1) Emotional Intimacy, 2) Physical Intimacy, 3) Intellectual Intimacy, 4) Supportive Intimacy, 5) Balanced Intimacy.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your primary intimacy style is Emotional Intimacy, indicating you prioritize sharing feelings and emotional connection in your relationship.

title: Growth Opportunity Style Assessment
research: Based on self-expansion theory and research on personal growth within relationships
description: Discover how you support your partner's personal growth while nurturing your relationship! This fun and insightful quiz will help you understand your growth support style and how it contributes to relationship satisfaction.

questions.question: How do you react when your partner shares a new personal goal?
options: Encourage them and discuss ways to help achieve it.
Feel excited and share your own related goals.
Support them but focus on your own interests as well.
Listen and provide practical advice when needed.
Celebrate their achievement without involving it in your own life.

questions.question: When thinking about your personal development, how important is your partner's growth to you?
options: It's just as important as my own growth.
I care a lot and actively support it.
I support it, but I prioritize my own growth more.
It's important, but I balance it with my personal goals.
I focus more on my growth and support theirs passively.

questions.question: How do you handle pursuing a new hobby or interest?
options: Invite your partner to join and explore it together.
Pursue it independently while encouraging your partner to do the same.
Integrate it with your partner's interests.
Keep it as a personal activity but share your experiences.
Focus on personal enjoyment without involving your partner.

questions.question: How often do you discuss personal goals with your partner?
options: Regularly, to align and support each other's goals.
Frequently, sharing and collaborating on goals.
Occasionally, when it seems relevant.
Rarely, keeping most goals private.
Almost never, I prefer to keep goals to myself.

questions.question: When your partner achieves a personal milestone, how do you respond?
options: Celebrate together and discuss future growth opportunities.
Express genuine happiness and encourage them to set new goals.
Acknowledge their success and maintain your own growth path.
Provide practical support and congratulate them.
Feel happy for them but continue focusing on your own achievements.

questions.question: How do you approach setting relationship goals?
options: Collaboratively set goals that foster mutual growth.
Set personal and relationship goals that complement each other.
Focus primarily on your personal goals within the relationship.
Balance both personal and relationship goals independently.
Keep relationship goals minimal to focus on personal development.

questions.question: How do you support your partner during challenging personal growth periods?
options: Provide emotional support and actively participate in their journey.
Encourage them and offer resources or assistance.
Give them space while being available when needed.
Offer practical help to alleviate their stress.
Respect their process and provide support when asked.

questions.question: How important is it for you to grow together as a couple?
options: Extremely important; we grow in tandem.
Very important; we support each other's growth.
Somewhat important; we grow individually and occasionally together.
Moderately important; we focus more on personal growth.
Not very important; we prioritize individual growth.

questions.question: How do you react when your partner develops a new skill or expertise?
options: Show interest and learn alongside them.
Encourage and appreciate their dedication.
Support their learning while continuing to develop my own skills.
Acknowledge their achievement and consider how it benefits us.
Feel proud for them and let them lead in that area.

questions.question: How do you integrate personal growth into your relationship?
options: Find activities that promote growth for both of us.
Share experiences that allow mutual development.
Support each other's individual growth paths.
Balance personal development with our relationship needs.
Maintain separate growth activities to keep personal independence.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following growth support styles: 1) Supportive Collaborator, 2) Mutual Growth Enthusiast, 3) Independent Growth Seeker, 4) Supportive Encourager, 5) Solo Developer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Growth Support Style is Supportive Collaborator, indicating you actively support both your and your partner's personal growth within the relationship.

title: Shared Meaning Style
research: Grounded in Gottman's Sound Relationship House Theory and research on shared meaning systems, this test assesses how couples create and maintain shared meaning in their relationship through rituals, goals, and values.
description: Discover how you and your partner build a shared meaning in your relationship! This fun quiz explores the rituals, goals, and values that bring you closer together, helping you strengthen your bond and future plans.

questions.question: How do you like to start your mornings with your partner?
options: Creating a morning ritual like having coffee together.
Discussing daily goals and plans for the day.
Sharing a quick hug or kiss before parting ways.
Exchanging positive affirmations or good wishes.
Allowing each other space to begin the day independently.

questions.question: When planning vacations, what is most important to you?
options: Establishing traditions, like visiting the same place every year.
Setting common goals for the trip, such as relaxation or adventure.
Ensuring there are plenty of activities to enjoy together.
Making spontaneous decisions based on how we feel.
Balancing each other's preferences to create a harmonious experience.

questions.question: How do you handle celebrating anniversaries or special occasions?
options: Having a specific ritual or tradition that we follow each year.
Planning together to set shared goals for the celebration.
Focusing on spending quality time and creating memories.
Surprising each other with unexpected gestures.
Ensuring the celebration aligns with both our values and preferences.

questions.question: When discussing future plans, what approach do you take?
options: Creating shared rituals that guide our future together.
Setting long-term goals that we both strive to achieve.
Focusing on activities and experiences we want to share.
Being flexible and open to changes as we go.
Aligning our values to ensure our future plans are compatible.

questions.question: How do you incorporate personal values into your relationship?
options: Establishing rituals that reflect our shared values.
Setting goals that are aligned with our individual and mutual values.
Ensuring our daily activities honor and reinforce our values.
Respecting each other's values and adapting as needed.
Communicating openly about how our values shape our relationship.

questions.question: What role do traditions play in your relationship?
options: They are central; we have many traditions that define our bond.
We create new traditions that support our shared goals.
We enjoy traditions that bring us joy and strengthen our connection.
We occasionally incorporate traditions based on circumstances.
We value traditions that reflect both our individual and shared values.

questions.question: How do you and your partner handle disagreements about future plans?
options: Develop rituals to reconcile and move forward together.
Set shared goals that help us find common ground.
Focus on understanding each other's perspectives and finding mutually enjoyable solutions.
Take time to cool off and revisit the discussion later.
Ensure that any decisions respect both of our values and aspirations.

questions.question: When creating a home environment, what is important to you?
options: Incorporating rituals that make our home unique.
Setting shared goals for how we want our home to function.
Designing a space that supports our shared activities and interests.
Allowing flexibility in how we organize and decorate.
Ensuring the home reflects both our individual and collective values.

questions.question: How do you and your partner support each other's personal growth?
options: Creating rituals that encourage continuous growth together.
Setting shared goals that include personal development.
Engaging in activities that foster mutual growth and learning.
Providing space and support for individual growth pursuits.
Aligning our values to support each other's aspirations.

questions.question: What is your approach to maintaining shared meaning during busy times?
options: Maintaining our rituals even when schedules are tight.
Revisiting and adjusting our goals to fit current circumstances.
Ensuring we still find time for shared activities.
Being spontaneous to keep the relationship lively.
Communicating openly to preserve our shared values and meaning.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Shared Meaning Styles: 1) Ritual Builder, 2) Goal Aligner, 3) Activity Connector, 4) Flexible Adapter, 5) Value Harmonizer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Shared Meaning Style is Ritual Builder, indicating you prioritize establishing and maintaining rituals to strengthen your relationship.

title: Novelty Integration Style
research: Based on hedonic adaptation prevention research and studies on maintaining relationship excitement
description: Measures your ability to maintain excitement and prevent relationship stagnation through healthy novelty and shared adventures.

questions.question: When planning a weekend together, how do you approach activities?
options: I always look for new and exciting things to do.
I often try a mix of new and familiar activities.
I sometimes introduce new activities but keep some favorites.
I rarely suggest new activities, preferring what we know.
I stick to our usual routines without adding anything new.

questions.question: How do you feel about spontaneous trips or surprises in your relationship?
options: I love spontaneous adventures and surprises!
I enjoy them occasionally when they fit our plans.
I'm okay with spontaneous things but prefer some notice.
I don't mind them but they aren't my thing.
I prefer to have everything planned and dislike surprises.

questions.question: When trying something new together, what's your usual excitement level?
options: I'm always super excited to try new things!
I'm usually excited and look forward to it.
I'm moderately excited and open to it.
I'm a bit hesitant but willing to try.
I'm not excited and prefer to avoid new things.

questions.question: How do you handle routine in your daily interactions?
options: I constantly seek to change our routines to keep things fresh.
I frequently introduce small changes to our routine.
I make occasional tweaks to our routine.
I rarely change our routine unless necessary.
I prefer sticking strictly to our established routines.

questions.question: When it comes to hobbies or interests, how do you share them with your partner?
options: I love introducing new hobbies and trying new interests together.
I often share new interests while keeping some personal hobbies.
I sometimes share hobbies if it feels right.
I rarely share new hobbies, sticking to our existing interests.
I keep my hobbies separate and don't introduce new ones.

questions.question: How do you react when your partner suggests doing something different?
options: I'm excited and immediately on board!
I'm happy to try something new together.
I'm open to it but have some reservations.
I'm hesitant but may agree to try.
I prefer not to change and keep things as they are.

questions.question: How often do you seek out new experiences or activities outside the relationship?
options: Very often – I love bringing new experiences into our relationship.
Frequently – I enjoy sharing new things with my partner.
Sometimes – I introduce new experiences occasionally.
Rarely – I seldom seek out new experiences.
Never – I don't pursue new experiences outside our usual activities.

questions.question: When facing a boring day, how do you try to shake things up?
