options: I immediately plan an exciting new activity.
I suggest trying something different to add some fun.
I might propose a small change to our routine.
I usually stick to our regular plans to keep things steady.
I prefer not to change anything and stay as we are.

questions.question: How important is variety in keeping your relationship exciting?
options: It's essential – variety keeps our relationship lively!
It's very important – I need variety to stay engaged.
It's somewhat important – a little variety is nice.
It's not very important – routine works for us.
It's not important at all – I prefer consistency.

questions.question: How do you balance tradition and novelty in your relationship?
options: I prioritize novelty and often set aside traditions.
I lean more towards novelty but keep some traditions.
I maintain a balanced mix of both tradition and novelty.
I favor tradition but occasionally incorporate some novelty.
I stick strictly to traditions and avoid new things.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Novelty Integration Styles: 1) Spontaneous Dynamo, 2) Frequent Trailblazer, 3) Balanced Innovator, 4) Occasional Adventurer, 5) Routine Explorer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 3) most frequently, your Novelty Integration Style is Balanced Innovator, indicating you find a healthy mix of new experiences and familiar routines to keep the relationship exciting.

title: Stress Support Style
research: Derived from stress-buffering hypothesis and research on dyadic coping in relationships
description: Find out how you support your partner during stressful times and how it affects your relationship satisfaction. Discover your unique stress buffer style and learn how to better protect your relationship from external pressures.

questions.question: When your partner is stressed, how do you typically respond?
options: I listen and offer a shoulder to cry on.
I try to solve the problem that's causing the stress.
I spend time with them to distract from the stress.
I give them advice to handle their feelings.
I give them space to deal with it on their own.

questions.question: How do you prefer to support your partner after a long, stressful day?
options: Provide a comforting hug and listen to their vent.
Help them tackle their to-do list.
Plan a fun activity to take their mind off things.
Discuss ways to improve the situation.
Allow them to unwind alone as they need.

questions.question: When faced with a stressful situation, what role do you take in supporting your partner?
options: I offer emotional reassurance and understanding.
I take action to fix the issue causing stress.
I accompany them through the stressful time.
I provide practical advice and solutions.
I keep a distance and let them manage it themselves.

questions.question: How do you help your partner cope with stress during disagreements?
options: I empathize with their feelings and validate them.
I focus on resolving the underlying problem.
I try to lighten the mood and reduce tension.
I suggest strategies to handle their emotions better.
I prefer not to interfere and let them handle it.

questions.question: What do you find most effective in supporting your partner under stress?
options: Being emotionally present and attentive.
Taking proactive steps to eliminate stressors.
Engaging in shared activities to relax together.
Offering guidance and comfort through advice.
Respecting their need for independence and privacy.

questions.question: How do you act when your partner is anxious about work?
options: I listen to their concerns and comfort them.
I help them find solutions to their work problems.
I spend time with them to distract them from work.
I provide tips to manage their workload better.
I let them handle their anxiety on their own.

questions.question: When your partner feels overwhelmed, what is your typical approach?
options: I offer a listening ear and emotional support.
I assist in organizing their tasks to reduce overwhelm.
I propose doing something fun together to lighten the mood.
I discuss ways they can improve their coping mechanisms.
I step back and give them space to deal with it.

questions.question: How do you help your partner recover from a particularly stressful event?
options: I provide comfort and reassure them they're not alone.
I take charge to fix any issues caused by the event.
I engage them in relaxing or enjoyable activities.
I help them strategize on how to prevent future stress.
I respect their need for solitude and self-care.

questions.question: What's your first instinct when your partner shares they're stressed?
options: To empathize and understand their feelings.
To find a practical solution to their stress.
To spend time together to help them relax.
To offer advice on managing their stress.
To give them space to process it themselves.

questions.question: How do you like to support your partner during high-pressure times?
options: By being emotionally supportive and present.
By tackling tasks that contribute to the pressure.
By sharing enjoyable activities to take their mind off stress.
By advising them on how to handle their responsibilities better.
By allowing them the freedom to manage stress independently.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following stress support styles: 1) Emotional Supporter, 2) Problem Solver, 3) Companion, 4) Counselor, 5) Independent.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Stress Support Style is Emotional Supporter, indicating you provide empathy and understanding during stressful times.

title: Relationship Balance Style
research: Grounded in work-life balance research and studies on relationship satisfaction in modern contexts, this test evaluates how individuals manage their personal needs alongside relationship demands and external commitments.
description: Discover your Relationship Balance Style! This insightful quiz helps you understand how you maintain satisfaction in your relationship while juggling personal aspirations, relationship responsibilities, and external obligations. Gain a deeper awareness of your balance strategies and enhance your connection with your partner.

questions.question: When your work schedule gets hectic, how do you ensure quality time with your partner?
options: I prioritize setting aside specific times to connect.
I struggle to find time and often end up working late.
I involve my partner in my work-related activities.
I rely on spontaneous moments to spend time together.
I feel overwhelmed and tend to withdraw.

questions.question: How do you handle personal hobbies or interests that take up significant time?
options: I balance them with relationship time by scheduling both.
I often neglect them to focus more on the relationship.
I share my hobbies with my partner to include them.
I pursue them independently without much coordination.
I feel guilty spending time on my own interests.

questions.question: When external commitments, like family events, arise, how do you manage them?
options: I communicate openly with my partner to find a suitable balance.
I prioritize external commitments over the relationship.
I try to include my partner in as many external activities as possible.
I handle external commitments without involving my partner.
I feel stressed and unsure how to proceed.

questions.question: How do you ensure your personal goals align with your relationship goals?
options: I regularly discuss and adjust our goals together.
I focus primarily on my personal goals, keeping relationship goals separate.
I seek ways to integrate my goals with our relationship objectives.
I let my partner take the lead in aligning our goals.
I find it challenging to align my goals with the relationship.

questions.question: When feeling pressured by multiple responsibilities, what's your coping strategy?
options: I prioritize tasks and communicate my needs with my partner.
I tend to ignore some responsibilities to reduce stress.
I seek support and share the load with my partner.
I try to manage everything on my own without burdening my partner.
I become overwhelmed and find it hard to cope.

questions.question: How do you maintain your individuality within the relationship?
options: By pursuing personal interests and encouraging my partner to do the same.
I often blend my identity with my partner's, focusing more on the relationship.
I incorporate my individuality into our shared activities.
I keep my individuality separate and rarely share it within the relationship.
I struggle to maintain my individuality while being in the relationship.

questions.question: When planning for the future, how do you balance personal aspirations with relationship plans?
options: I discuss and integrate both personal and relationship aspirations.
I prioritize relationship plans over personal aspirations.
I focus more on my personal goals while considering the relationship.
I leave the balance to naturally evolve without specific planning.
I find it difficult to balance and often feel conflicted.

questions.question: How do you manage stress from external sources without affecting your relationship?
options: I address external stress through healthy coping mechanisms and communicate with my partner.
I keep my stress to myself, avoiding discussing it with my partner.
I let my partner help me manage the external stress.
I externalize my stress, which sometimes impacts the relationship.
I find it hard to keep external stress from affecting the relationship.

questions.question: How often do you reassess and adjust the balance between your personal life and relationship?
options: Regularly, to ensure both areas are fulfilling.
Rarely, once things are settled I maintain the status quo.
Only when significant changes occur in one area.
Seldom, relying on spontaneous adjustments.
I don't usually reassess and find it challenging to adjust.

questions.question: What role does communication play in maintaining balance in your relationship?
options: It's essential; we openly discuss our needs and adjustments.
It's somewhat important, though not always consistent.
It's useful, but we often find other ways to maintain balance.
It's minimally involved; we prefer handling balance independently.
It's challenging; we struggle to communicate about balance.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following balance styles: 1) Strategic Balancer, 2) Overcommitted, 3) Integrated Partner, 4) Independent Manager, 5) Stressed Balancer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Relationship Balance Style is Strategic Balancer, indicating you effectively manage and prioritize both personal and relationship needs.

title: Conversation Depth Style
research: Based on research in deep communication and vulnerability, highlighting the value of moving beyond surface-level conversations.
description: This theme encourages couples to go beyond routine topics, fostering deeper conversations that reveal more about each other's thoughts, dreams, and experiences.

questions.question: When your partner shares something important, how do you usually respond?
options: I ask follow-up questions to understand better.
I share a similar experience from my own life.
I listen quietly without saying much.
I express my feelings about what they shared.
I sometimes change the topic to something lighter.

questions.question: How do you feel about discussing your dreams and aspirations with your partner?
options: I love sharing my dreams and hearing theirs.
I share occasionally when it feels right.
I prefer to keep my aspirations to myself.
I often talk about how we can achieve our goals together.
I feel nervous bringing up my dreams.

questions.question: When faced with a problem, how do you approach discussing it with your partner?
options: I bring it up immediately to find a solution together.
I think it over first before discussing it.
I might avoid the conversation to prevent conflict.
I express my emotions and seek support.
I prefer to handle it on my own without much discussion.

questions.question: How often do you initiate deep or meaningful conversations with your partner?
options: Regularly, as part of our routine.
Sometimes, when something significant comes up.
Rarely, we mostly stick to casual topics.
Frequently, especially when we're together.
Only when prompted by my partner.

questions.question: What topics do you find most engaging for deep conversations?
options: Personal growth and self-improvement.
Future plans and aspirations.
Our relationship and feelings for each other.
Life challenges and how to overcome them.
Everyday experiences and observations.

questions.question: How comfortable are you with showing vulnerability in conversations with your partner?
options: Very comfortable, I openly share my feelings.
Comfortable, but I choose what to share carefully.
Somewhat uncomfortable, I hold back often.
Uncomfortable, I rarely show vulnerability.
It depends on the situation and my mood.

questions.question: When your partner shares their thoughts, how do you react?
options: I engage actively and add my perspective.
I listen attentively and provide feedback.
I might get distracted or think about something else.
I validate their feelings and experiences.
I struggle to respond appropriately.

questions.question: How do you ensure that your conversations with your partner remain meaningful?
options: We set aside time regularly to talk deeply.
We bring up topics that matter to us.
We ask each other thoughtful questions.
We create a safe space for open dialogue.
We rely on spontaneous conversations without planning.

questions.question: What role does active listening play in your meaningful conversations?
options: It's central; I make sure to fully understand.
It's important, but sometimes challenging.
I try, but often find my mind wandering.
I prioritize listening over sharing my own thoughts.
I find it difficult to practice active listening.

questions.question: How do you handle silence during meaningful conversations?
options: I embrace it as time to reflect.
I feel comfortable and let it be.
I try to fill the silence with more talk.
I sometimes feel uneasy and move the conversation.
I use it as an opportunity to change the topic.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following conversation depth styles: 1) Surface-level Conversationalist, 2) Occasional Deep Diver, 3) Consistent Deep Speaker, 4) Emotionally Open Communicator, 5) Structured Dialogue Enthusiast.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 4) most frequently, your Conversation Depth Style is Emotionally Open Communicator, indicating you readily share your feelings and seek emotional connections in conversations.

title: Curious Communicator Type
research: Grounded in Carl Rogers' theory of unconditional positive regard and active curiosity, this test explores how individuals engage in meaningful conversations within their relationships.
description: Ever wondered how your curiosity shapes your conversations? Take this light-hearted quiz to discover your Curious Communicator Type and learn how you can foster deeper connections with your partner through open-hearted dialogue.

questions.question: When your partner shares something important, how do you typically respond?
options: Ask follow-up questions to understand better.
Nod and offer a brief comment.
Share a related personal story.
Change the topic to something lighter.
Listen quietly without saying much.

questions.question: How do you feel about discussing your partner's feelings?
options: I actively seek to understand and support them.
I feel comfortable but don't always initiate the conversation.
I share my thoughts when they bring it up.
I find it challenging and prefer to avoid deep discussions.
I often feel overwhelmed and unsure how to respond.

questions.question: When exploring new topics with your partner, you:
options: Dive deep and ask insightful questions.
Stay on familiar subjects that interest both of you.
Introduce playful and fun topics.
Keep the conversation surface-level to maintain harmony.
Feel hesitant to introduce new ideas.

questions.question: How do you handle it when your partner shares a different perspective?
options: Embrace it and discuss it openly.
Acknowledge it and share your own view.
Use it as an opportunity to find common ground.
Respect it but change the subject.
Feel defensive and withdraw from the conversation.

questions.question: In conversations, you prefer to:
options: Explore emotions and underlying motivations.
Focus on practical and actionable topics.
Keep things light and entertaining.
Ensure that both partners feel heard and valued.
Avoid delving too deep into sensitive areas.

questions.question: When faced with a misunderstanding, you:
options: Seek to clarify and resolve it through dialogue.
Give it some time before addressing it.
Use humor to diffuse the situation.
Apologize and move on quickly.
Feel stressed and avoid discussing it.

questions.question: How often do you initiate deep or meaningful conversations with your partner?
options: Regularly, as a way to connect and understand each other.
Sometimes, when the mood feels right.
Rarely, preferring to focus on day-to-day topics.
Only when there's an issue to address.
Almost never, as I find them uncomfortable.

questions.question: When your partner shares their dreams and aspirations, you:
options: Encourage and ask more about their goals.
Listen and offer support where needed.
Share your own aspirations in response.
Compliment their ambitions and move to another topic.
Feel unsure how to respond and stay quiet.

questions.question: During a conversation, if you find yourself lost for words, you:
options: Take a moment to think of a thoughtful response.
Change the subject smoothly.
Use a light comment to keep the flow.
Acknowledge that you need a moment to process.
Stay silent until the other person speaks again.

questions.question: How do you feel about sharing your own vulnerabilities in conversations?
options: Comfortable and see it as a way to deepen connection.
Open to it but prefer not to overshare.
Only share when necessary or prompted.
Prefer to keep vulnerabilities private to protect the relationship.
Find it difficult and often avoid sharing.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Curious Communicator Types: 1) Deep Explorer, 2) Supportive Listener, 3) Playful Conversationalist, 4) Harmonious Responder, 5) Reserved Reflector.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Curious Communicator Type is Deep Explorer, indicating you actively seek to understand and connect through meaningful and in-depth conversations.

title: Reflective Listening Style
research: Based on reflective listening techniques in psychology.
description: Discover your unique reflective listening style! This quiz helps you understand how you engage in meaningful conversations, ensuring both you and your partner feel heard and valued.

questions.question: When your partner shares something important, how do you typically respond?
options: I ask detailed questions to understand better.
I express empathy and acknowledge their feelings.
I analyze the information and provide logical feedback.
I offer support and reassurance.
I listen quietly without much verbal response.

questions.question: During a disagreement, how do you ensure your partner feels heard?
options: I paraphrase their points to show understanding.
I focus on their emotions and validate their feelings.
I break down the issues logically to find solutions.
I offer comforting words and physical support.
I prefer to listen without adding my perspective.

questions.question: When your partner shares good news, what is your reaction?
options: I ask for more details to celebrate together.
I express genuine happiness for them.
I discuss the implications and future steps.
I give them a hug or a pat on the back.
I smile and listen without much commentary.

questions.question: How do you handle it when your partner is upset?
options: I ask questions to fully understand the situation.
I empathize and acknowledge their feelings.
I try to find practical solutions to help.
I provide comfort through actions and words.
I stay silent and let them process their feelings.

questions.question: When having a deep conversation, what's your role?
options: I lead the discussion with probing questions.
I focus on connecting emotionally and sharing feelings.
I contribute by analyzing topics and offering insights.
I ensure the conversation remains positive and supportive.
I listen attentively without interjecting much.

questions.question: After listening to your partner, how do you usually respond?
options: I summarize what they've said to confirm understanding.
I reflect on their emotions and express empathy.
I provide feedback based on the information shared.
I offer support and suggest ways to help.
I nod and show that I'm listening without adding much.

questions.question: How do you show your partner that you are listening?
options: I maintain eye contact and ask clarifying questions.
I respond with affirming statements and gestures.
I connect their points to past conversations logically.
I use comforting words and physical touch.
I listen without interrupting or adding comments.

questions.question: When your partner talks about their day, what do you do?
options: I inquire further to get a complete picture.
I empathize with their experiences and feelings.
I discuss the events and possible outcomes.
I comfort them and offer support.
I listen passively and wait for them to finish.

questions.question: How do you prefer to handle feedback from your partner?
options: I ask questions to understand the feedback fully.
I listen and acknowledge their perspective.
I evaluate the feedback logically and respond accordingly.
I accept and show appreciation for their input.
I take it in silently without much discussion.

questions.question: In conversations, how do you balance speaking and listening?
options: I actively engage with questions and follow-ups.
I prioritize listening to understand their feelings first.
I contribute thoughts and analysis regularly.
I ensure the conversation stays supportive and positive.
I mostly listen and speak only when necessary.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following reflective listening styles: 1) Active Listener, 2) Empathetic Responder, 3) Analytical Reflector, 4) Supportive Communicator, 5) Reserved Listener.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Reflective Listening Style is Active Listener, indicating you engage deeply by asking questions and seeking to fully understand your partner.

title: Future Vision Type
research: Drawn from research on the importance of sharing future hopes in relationship satisfaction.
description: Discover how your dreams and desires align with your partner's. This quiz helps you understand each other's aspirations and personal goals, fostering a deeper connection and mutual support.

questions.question: When you think about your future, what excites you the most?
options: Achieving professional goals and career growth.
Building a loving family and home.
Traveling the world and experiencing new cultures.
Engaging in creative pursuits and hobbies.
Ensuring financial stability and security.

questions.question: How do you approach setting personal goals?
options: I create detailed plans and set clear milestones.
I prioritize goals that enhance my relationships.
I seek out adventurous and spontaneous opportunities.
I focus on creative and self-expressive objectives.
I aim for goals that provide stability and reliability.

questions.question: What role does your partner play in your future aspirations?
options: They inspire and challenge me to reach higher.
They are my primary support and motivation.
We plan exciting adventures together.
They encourage my creativity and personal growth.
They help me maintain stability and balance.

questions.question: What is your ideal way to celebrate achieving a major goal?
options: Advancing my career with a promotion party.
Hosting a family gathering to share the joy.
Planning a spontaneous trip or adventure.
Creating a personal project or artwork.
Ensuring everything is financially secure before celebrating.

questions.question: How do you handle setbacks in pursuing your dreams?
options: Analyze what went wrong and adjust my strategy.
Seek support and encouragement from loved ones.
Take a break and seek new experiences to regain motivation.
Channel my energy into creative solutions.
Focus on maintaining stability and avoiding further risks.

questions.question: What gives you the most satisfaction when working towards a goal?
options: Seeing tangible progress and achievements.
Strengthening bonds with those around me.
Experiencing new and exciting challenges.
Expressing myself creatively and innovatively.
Building a secure and reliable foundation.

questions.question: How do you envision your retirement?
options: Continuing to grow professionally or start a new business.
Enjoying time with family and friends.
Traveling to new and exotic places.
Engaging in creative hobbies and projects.
Living comfortably with financial security.

questions.question: What motivates you to pursue your long-term goals?
options: Personal ambition and desire for success.
Creating a loving and supportive environment.
The thrill of new experiences and adventures.
The freedom to express myself creatively.
The need for financial independence and security.

questions.question: How do you prefer to discuss future plans with your partner?
options: Setting specific goals and outlining steps to achieve them.
Talking about our dreams and how to support each other.
Brainstorming exciting and unconventional ideas together.
Sharing creative visions and collaborative projects.
Ensuring our plans are financially sound and secure.

questions.question: What is most important to you when planning for the future?
options: Having a clear and achievable roadmap.
Fostering strong and meaningful relationships.
Embracing flexibility and new opportunities.
Incorporating creativity and personal fulfillment.
Maintaining stability and minimizing risks.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Future Vision Types: 1) Career-driven Planner, 2) Family-focused Nurturer, 3) Adventurous Explorer, 4) Creative Dreamer, 5) Secure Stabilizer.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Future Vision Type is Career-driven Planner, indicating you prioritize professional growth and strategic planning in your life.

title: Values in Action Type
research: Based on values clarification theory in psychology.
description: This theme helps couples discuss how their values manifest in daily life, encouraging meaningful exchanges about what truly matters to each person and the relationship.

questions.question: When deciding how to spend your weekend, what do you prioritize the most?
options: Spending quality time with family and loved ones.
Working on personal projects or career development.
Trying out a new hobby or exploring a new place.
Volunteering or participating in community events.
Engaging in activities that promote personal growth and learning.

questions.question: How do you handle conflicts between your personal goals and relationship commitments?
options: Always put the relationship first to maintain harmony.
Focus on your career or personal goals, sometimes at the expense of the relationship.
Seek a balance by finding activities that satisfy both personal and relationship goals.
Involve the community or seek external support to resolve the conflict.
Use the conflict as an opportunity for personal growth and reflection.

questions.question: What motivates you to make sacrifices in your daily life?
options: To ensure the happiness and well-being of your family.
To achieve long-term career success and recognition.
To gain new experiences and broaden your horizons.
To contribute positively to your community and society.
To develop new skills and improve yourself personally.

questions.question: When planning a major life decision, what aspect do you consider most important?
options: How it will affect your family and loved ones.
The potential for career advancement and financial gain.
The opportunity for adventure and new experiences.
The impact it will have on your community involvement.
How it will contribute to your personal development.

questions.question: How do you celebrate your achievements?
options: By sharing the moment with family and friends.
By investing in further career opportunities or education.
By embarking on a new adventure or experience.
By giving back to the community or helping others.
By reflecting on your growth and setting new personal goals.

questions.question: What type of gift do you appreciate the most?
options: A family photo album or something that brings loved ones together.
A professional development course or career-related tool.
Tickets to an exciting event or a new travel destination.
A donation made in your name to a charity you support.
A book or workshop that fosters personal growth.

questions.question: How do you prefer to spend a relaxing evening?
options: Having dinner with family or close friends.
Working on a personal project or studying for career growth.
Trying out a new activity or exploring a new place.
Participating in a community event or volunteering.
Engaging in a self-improvement activity like reading or meditating.

questions.question: What aspect of your life do you strive to improve the most?
options: Strengthening relationships with family and friends.
Advancing your career and professional skills.
Seeking new adventures and experiences.
Enhancing your role within the community.
Focusing on personal development and self-improvement.

questions.question: When faced with a choice, what guides your decision-making?
options: The needs and feelings of your loved ones.
Career benefits and long-term professional goals.
The potential for fun and new experiences.
The positive impact on your community.
Opportunities for learning and personal growth.

questions.question: How do you define success in your life?
options: Having a happy and supportive family life.
Achieving significant milestones in your career.
Having a life full of adventures and varied experiences.
Making meaningful contributions to your community.
Constantly growing and evolving as an individual.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following values in action types: 1) Family-Oriented, 2) Career-Focused, 3) Adventure-Seeker, 4) Community-Minded, 5) Personal Growth-Focused.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Values in Action Type is Family-Oriented, indicating you prioritize family and relationships in your daily life.

title: Life Story Style
research: Based on narrative psychology, which underscores the importance of sharing personal stories.
description: This theme encourages couples to share their life stories, creating space for each partner's past experiences, family history, and memories, which builds empathy and understanding.

questions.question: When you talk about your childhood with your partner, you:
options: Dive deep into your experiences and discuss their meanings.
Share only the most important moments without too much detail.
Get excited to share every little detail and keep the conversation lively.
Prefer listening to their stories and offer support when needed.
Tend to keep your personal stories private and share only when necessary.

questions.question: How do you like to share stories from your past?
options: Explore the emotions and lessons learned from each experience.
Highlight key events that shaped who you are.
Enthusiastically recount events with lots of details.
Focus more on listening and responding to your partner's stories.
Share only when your partner asks and keep it brief.

questions.question: When recalling past events, you tend to:
options: Reflect on how they influenced your personal growth.
Summarize the main points efficiently.
Share animatedly with enthusiasm.
Listen attentively when your partner shares their memories.
Feel hesitant to talk about personal experiences.

questions.question: Sharing memories with your partner makes you feel:
options: Connected and introspective about your journey together.
Content sharing just the highlights.
Energized by reminiscing and adding new details.
Supportive and engaged by hearing their stories.
Uncomfortable and prefer to keep things light.

questions.question: When discussing your family history, you:
options: Delve into the details and significance of family traditions.
Provide a brief overview of important family events.
Share interesting family stories with flair.
Listen more and encourage your partner to share their history.
Keep family discussions to a minimum.

questions.question: How often do you talk about past experiences with your partner?
options: Regularly, and we often explore their deeper meanings.
Occasionally, focusing on key life moments.
Frequently, enjoying the narrative and excitement.
When prompted, preferring to listen more than share.
Rarely, as I tend to keep my past experiences private.

questions.question: When sharing your stories, you prefer to:
options: Analyze and discuss the impact of each story.
Keep it concise and to the point.
Add humorous or entertaining details to keep it fun.
Encourage your partner to share and listen actively.
Share only essential information without elaboration.

questions.question: Reflecting on your past with your partner, you:
options: Enjoy exploring how past experiences have shaped your relationship.
Prefer to highlight significant milestones.
Love to narrate past events with enthusiasm and joy.
Focus on listening and understanding their past.
Feel indifferent and avoid delving into past stories.

questions.question: When your partner shares their life story, you:
options: Engage deeply and discuss its implications.
Appreciate the main points and move forward.
Respond with similar enthusiasm and share related stories.
Listen attentively and provide supportive feedback.
Stay quiet and keep your reactions minimal.

questions.question: Sharing personal memories helps you:
options: Gain a deeper understanding of yourself and your relationship.
Recall important events without overanalyzing.
Enjoy reliving experiences and adding new perspectives.
Connect by supporting each other's storytelling.
Keep conversations light and avoid heavy topics.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the Life Story Styles: 1) Reflective Storyteller, 2) Concise Narrator, 3) Enthusiastic Shareer, 4) Listener-Focused, and 5) Reserved Storyteller.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 3) most frequently, your Life Story Style is Enthusiastic Shareer, meaning you love sharing detailed and engaging stories about your past experiences.

title: Silence Comfort Style
research: Grounded in research on the value of silence and presence in relationships.
description: This theme teaches couples to embrace comfortable silences, cultivating a peaceful connection that doesn't rely on constant conversation but fosters a sense of calm companionship.

questions.question: When you're enjoying a quiet evening together, how do you feel most at ease?
options: I feel peaceful and content just being together in silence.
I enjoy being present and sharing the quiet moments without feeling the need to talk.
I like having some conversation but also appreciate moments of silence.
I prefer to engage in lively discussions to keep the evening active.
I enjoy a mix of quiet moments and engaging conversations.

questions.question: How do you handle moments of silence during a date?
options: I embrace the silence and enjoy the calmness it brings.
I appreciate the silence and use it to connect on a deeper level.
I'm comfortable with occasional silence but like to talk more often.
I feel the need to fill the silence with conversation to stay connected.
I seek a balance between enjoying silence and having meaningful talks.

questions.question: When watching a movie together, what best describes your preferred interaction?
options: We quietly enjoy the movie without much conversation.
I quietly share reactions without the need for extensive talking.
We discuss parts of the movie intermittently but also enjoy silence.
I like to comment and discuss the movie actively as we watch.
We alternate between watching in silence and discussing key scenes.

questions.question: How do you feel about sitting together without speaking?
options: I find it comforting and enjoy the peacefulness of silence.
I enjoy the presence without the need for words.
I'm okay with it occasionally but prefer some conversation.
I feel uneasy and prefer to keep the conversation going.
I enjoy both sitting in silence and having regular conversations.

questions.question: During a relaxed morning, what's your preferred way to spend time with your partner?
options: We quietly enjoy our own activities side by side.
We sit together peacefully without the need to talk.
We share some conversation but also enjoy silent moments.
We engage in lively discussions to start the day energetically.
We enjoy a combination of quiet time and meaningful conversations.

questions.question: When you both read together, how do you interact?
options: We read in silence and feel connected through our shared presence.
I quietly observe and appreciate the silent activity together.
We read quietly but discuss interesting points occasionally.
I prefer to talk about what I'm reading rather than stay silent.
We read silently and then share our thoughts and discuss afterwards.

questions.question: How do you feel about taking solitary walks together?
options: I enjoy walking side by side in silence and sharing the peacefulness.
I appreciate the quiet time together while each reflects personally.
I like walking together with some moments of conversation.
I prefer to talk and share thoughts while walking together.
I enjoy a mix of walking in silence and engaging in conversations during the walk.

questions.question: When relaxing without a specific activity, what best describes your behavior?
options: I enjoy simply being together in silence without the need for activities.
I appreciate the quiet presence of my partner while doing nothing specific.
I'm comfortable doing nothing together but like to engage occasionally.
I tend to find ways to start conversations or activities to keep us engaged.
I enjoy periods of doing nothing along with times when we interact.

questions.question: How do you feel after spending time in comfortable silence with your partner?
options: I feel calm and more connected.
I feel content and appreciated for just being present.
I feel relaxed but also a desire to talk sometimes.
I feel like I need to talk more to feel connected.
I feel balanced, enjoying both the silence and conversations.

questions.question: What is your preferred way to end a peaceful day together?
options: We sit together quietly and enjoy the end of the day in silence.
I appreciate the silence and the calm it brings before bedtime.
We share some final thoughts but also enjoy quiet moments.
I like to talk about our day and share experiences energetically.
We enjoy a peaceful moment of silence followed by a meaningful conversation.

evaluation_method.explanation: Each answer corresponds to one of the following Silence Comfort Styles: 1) Peaceful Reflective, 2) Comfortable Listener, 3) Occasional Talker, 4) Active Communicator, 5) Balanced Partner.
evaluation_method.example: For example, if you selected option 1) most frequently, your Silence Comfort Style is Peaceful Reflective, indicating you find calmness and contentment in shared silences.
